name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Soraya Post and Teresa Jiménez—Becerril Barrio, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on the implementation of Directive 2011/99/EU on the European Protection Order (2016/2329(INI)) (A8-0065/2018).

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I had the honour of working on the implementation report on the European Protection Order Directive, which, if it works, can save the lives of victims of gender-based violence and other forms of interpersonal violence. It is one of those EU initiatives that can save tens of thousands of lives and we need to save them today, in Europe.  One in three women has experienced physical or sexual violence since the age of 15. Every second woman has been a victim of sexual harassment. Women and girls living with disabilities in Europe are two to five times more likely to be victims of violence than non-disabled women.  Around 20% of European children are victims of sexual violence, most of which is committed by someone very close to them. One in five women has experienced stalking. One in four Roma people are victims of hate—motivated harassment and crimes. Thousands of LGBTI people are attacked or threatened with violence. There are tens of thousands of people who need protection. However, there have only been seven European Protection Orders (EPOs) issued in the whole of Europe so far.  For me, as a feminist, it is very frustrating to see that there is a tool that could be used but is not. For me, it clearly shows that, so far, neither the Commission nor the Member States have taken their responsibilities very seriously. Public servants who come into contact with victims do not know about this international protection instrument. Victim protection organisations do not know about this instrument. The victims themselves have hardly ever heard of the opportunity that they have to take their already existing national protection orders with them abroad when they want to travel or move to another EU country.  This Directive came into force in 2011. Member States had four years to implement it into their national laws by 11 January 2015. How many years do we have to wait until this Directive is properly implemented and provides protection for those who need it? This shameful situation has to change. Therefore, in our draft report we formulated several pages of demands, some of which are the following:  We call on the Commission and the Member States to make sure that information about EPOs really reaches the victims, the NGOs and the authorities that are working with these issues;  We call for mandatory training of professionals likely to come in contact with victims; We call on Member States to automatically inform persons who get a national protection order about the EPO and making the application process free of charge, shorter and easier for victims; We call for special measures to be implemented by the Member States for victims in vulnerable situations or victims with specific needs, such as children;  We call for free legal aid, translation and interpretation into a language understood by the victim; We call for a decision on the EPO request to be delivered within a maximum of two weeks; Given the increasing exposure of children and teenagers to violence online, we call on Member States to include education on gender equality and non—violence in the school curriculum;  Since the EU has focused its security agenda purely on its external aspect, we call on the Commission and the Council to place the issue of interpersonal security on the EU security agenda.  I would like to ask all colleagues to help us in our fight and to help to spread the word about this protection instrument so that everybody can exercise their right to live free from violence and the fear of it in our Europe. I would like to thank my co-rapporteur, Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio, and all the shadows and all the colleagues who tabled amendments to this report, which make it strong. I hope for a successful voting outcome today, of course, and wish us all good luck. This is not acceptable.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, I would also like to thank the co-rapporteur, Soraya, and all the people who have helped us. As a victim of terrorism since the ETA terrorist organisation murdered my brother and his wife, since I entered this Parliament I have always taken care of defending the rights of the victims: of all victims — especially terrorism, but of all. I was therefore very pleased when this report was submitted in 2010 and was assigned to me; and I remember that we all had a lot of expectations about this report, because it would be a dynamic mechanism to avoid bureaucracy and improve the lives of victims. The EPO was the result of the Stockholm Programme, which required coherent political responses in the area of freedom, security and justice. We were not talking about creating a convergence of national laws, we were talking about a mechanism for judicial cooperation. However, this instrument, as it is currently found, has failed. It was estimated in 2010, when this Directive was introduced, that 100,000 women residing in the European Union had orders for protection of some kind for gender-based violence. Well, we know that only seven orders have been issued: four in Spain, two in the UK and one in Italy. That's a shocking scarce thing. Therefore, the question we have to ask ourselves — Parliament, Commission, all of us... also the Member States — is what has failed, and try with this implementation to give recommendations to the States and see what we have seen, because what we have to do is save lives and improve the lives of the victims. Since this directive came into force, we have no data from the European Commission, nor from the Member States. Even NGOs have not been able to collect data, because there are no data. With so few resources, it is good that we had the study of the European Parliament's Studies Service and, from there, we have shown quite a lot shortcomings. For example — I will quote a few of them — there is no central register of European orders, which makes it very difficult to assess them: the instrument itself is very complex — this is important — because it complicates the implementation of the Directive by national authorities and also complicates the understanding of the victims of this directive. There is no special provision for vulnerable persons, such as children, as persons with disabilities. There is a huge lack of training for national authorities: the implementation of the EPO in each country was not monitored; there is a huge gap between coordination and communication between Member States which have to implement the European order. Victims are not offered translation, which is necessary for a European protection order. As far as victims are concerned, an important aspect is that the protected person must be given adequate information on how to apply for such an order in another Member State. We have seen a general lack of information and awareness-raising campaigns: neither the police, nor the judges, nor the victims... no one knows this order. How are they going to ask for something that is unknown? Because, really, it's been ignored. I think it can be said that all the victims in this process will face some problem because they have to go from one country to another: if no one helps them, then they really prefer not to ask for it, and not even their lawyers... nobody advises them to do so. Therefore, we need to change coordination and communication between the authorities. We also call on the Commission to establish a European registration system to collect information on EPO from all Member States. We stress these legal and practical shortcomings. And, well, all I would say is that European citizens are really asking us for greater judicial cooperation. Victim Protection Orders and Victim Protection Orders are not working well euroorders for deliveries of aggressors. Europe is therefore not just the CAP, it is not just the euro, although they are very important; Europe is justice, freedom and security for all European citizens.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first, let me start by pointing out that all of the participating Member States have transposed the Directive on the European Protection Order. The Commission will issue the report on the application of the Directive on the EPO later this year. However, only today, the data already made available by the Member States also confirms that only a handful of European Protection Orders have been issued so far, as was rightly stated by the rapporteurs. We share your view that we have to improve awareness among practitioners about this instrument. This is why we are actively promoting the EPO. In particular, for now, we have collected practical information about national authorities competent to issue and recognise a European Protection Order. This is published on the websites of the European Judicial Networks in Criminal Matters and in Civil Matters. We have prepared an electronic version of the certificate on European Protection Orders in civil matters. This is quite a useful tool for judges. It is published on the e-Justice portal. We have also funded training materials on the EPO for judges. This information will soon be available on a dedicated training platform, also on the e-Justice portal. The Commission continues to fund activities under the Justice, Judicial Training, and Rights, Equality and Citizenship programmes which can include awareness-raising campaigns on European Protection Orders. We also continue to raise awareness with national experts from Member States; most recently, on 29 January this year, at the High Level Experts meeting on victims’ rights.  Finally, the Commission is carefully monitoring how Member States have transposed the provisions of the Victims’ Rights Directive requiring that victims must be informed about available protection, including in cross—border cases, from the first—contact authorities.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, today we will vote on how to better protect victims of crime on an EU-wide scale, which in practice concerns mainly victims of domestic violence. To date, this type of protection works weakly. A woman subjected to domestic violence can apply for a national protection order preventing an abusive husband from entering a communal apartment, for example. The moment a woman leaves her country for another country (for vacation or work), she is already insufficiently protected from the rapist. Why? According to 2010 statistics, there were already about 120,000 women subjected to violence eight years ago in the EU who received a national protection order. The vast majority of them do not know that they can be protected in other Member States. To date, just 7 (words seven) European protection orders have been put on display. This is due to the failure of Member States to broadly communicate to victims the possibility of international protection and reprehensible unawareness of this instrument. Our report appeals to justice authorities and professionals defending victims to change this. Victims of violence must be informed of their rights.

name: Anna HEDH
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President! First, I would like to thank everyone involved for good cooperation on this very important issue. We need to speak plainly. Protective orders are effectively used to protect women who are victims of violence in close relationships, domestic violence, where harassment, stalking or sexual assault often occur. Violence against women is a brutal form of discrimination and a violation of human rights. In the EU, gender violence is a growing problem. Every third woman in the EU has been subjected to physical or sexual violence. It is not just harmful to the women who are subjected to violence, but to the whole society at large. It is therefore important that the European protection order works, that victims who have been protected identity, restraining orders or otherwise receive information that it exists and that they find out about their rights and opportunities. Equally important, it is that the designated authorities of the Member States gain knowledge of the implementation. I am very supportive of the lifting of victims of crime victims in human trafficking in particular, as it is a very vulnerable group that needs greater protection. The Istanbul Convention sets out specific measures to protect the rights of victims of crime. Fully implementing the Istanbul Convention will strengthen protections for those who are exposed. It is therefore very important that all EU Member States immediately support the Istanbul Convention. It would be particularly desirable for the Presidency Bulgaria to take the lead and show other countries that have not yet ratified it the importance of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President, colleagues. Let's just imagine that we really could pass a law that effectively starts to defend violence. That means people will stop committing violence. So this would be a really amazing law that we would simply issue, and the violence would cease. Well, imagine that we here in this hall could simply stop the violence, have such a special power, give an order, and that would prevent people in intimate relationships from simply stopping each other's physical, emotional wounds, hurting their surroundings, just, stop would harm each other and do yourself wrong. Ultimately, that's our intention. We'd like to see it that way. If I could assert that, my entire mandate would be worth it. But it has to be said that the relevant statistics show that the real causes of domestic violence are drugs, alcohol, gambling, that is, gambling, and the wrong way of dealing with partner relationships. These are the biggest causes of the violence that's happening. And that's what we need to focus on. In fact, it's between a third to half of cases that all partner couples report some type of violence in their relationships. Sadly, protecting someone with an order in another state simply won't work, and we need to focus on explaining to people what violence is. And they not only issued an order that does not work. Especially when referring to the dubious Istanbul Convention.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this morning we are discussing a very important subject in this House. The subject is important not only for the functioning of the European institutions, but simply for the citizens and, in particular, for European citizens who are victims of violence and suffer this type of attack on their integrity. I remember that in 2010, in the Victims Package, many of us in this House worked hard to achieve an important and useful tool that protects victims in Europe. At the same time, for us Europeans, it was a legal and logical expression of European integration. Along with the mobility of Europeans, we proposed, with this tool, protection of Europeans, especially when they are victims of violence. What a sad observation, as the rapporteurs have recalled, to observe — and it is good to take stock of the use of the tools — that there have been seven protection decisions! This figure has no relation to the number of victims in Europe. Today, of course, we can see the multitude of reasons: information, the diversity of national legislation, and cooperation which is not sufficiently thorough. Obviously, we must emphasize and achieve real results on information, training and mobilization of States. We are counting on the Commission to do so as well as on the Member States.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, the European Protection Order is a great instrument, which makes it possible to protect women throughout the European Union who are victims of gender-based violence, but it is a great instrument, as the rapporteurs have said, with a very serious problem of implementation. Only seven orders issued since the launch of this instrument is a very poor result. And I want to make some thoughts. One that is already being done by the rapporteurs: you, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, have gone very late with the implementation report, which we do not yet have. And taking this instrument seriously is also to make such implementation reports and to know exactly whether the Member States are implementing it properly or not. We have a problem of harmonisation, too, of the types, because it is true that certain issues, such as harassment, which are covered by one legal system in another are not, and therefore that makes the instrument lose strength. And some of the elements that the Commissioner did mention and which are important: information for victims and training for those who are at the first meeting point with a victim (police officers, officials), who must know that this instrument exists. Gender-based violence therefore remains a very serious problem at European Union level. We have a good instrument. Let's all make an effort to make it work.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Madam President, the response of the states has fallen far short of what is needed in implementing the fair measures that the directive enshrines. Moreover, it is not surprising, therefore, that only seven European protection decisions have been identified in the context of the approximately one hundred thousand women living in the EU who are estimated to be under this directive. At a time when violence against women is increasing and almost trivialized, how often with total impunity, how often with lethal consequences, whether through domestic violence, harassment and sexual assault, trafficking in human beings, sexual exploitation and prostitution, are required of the States to take measures unequivocal measures aimed at protecting victims, measures which are often incompatible with the macroeconomic guidelines that the EU imposes. They go through the strengthening of the social functions of the State, investing in the human and technical qualification of the security and judicial forces, social security, and health, or in the creation of public networks to support victims, always ensuring communication and interpretation mechanisms, an obstacle to effective assistance to victim.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this report concerns the failure of the implementation of the European Protection Order (EPO). The EPO is just one of a raft of EU legal instruments intended to bring about an EU system of criminal law. This one concerns the mutual recognition of protection orders. The whole doctrine of mutual recognition is based on the fiction that every Member State’s legal system, police system and penal system is of equal standing, which is not true. The EPO doesn’t work, as only seven have ever been issued. But they are just part of a whole range of legal institutions and legal instruments that Ms May intends to incorporate into English law when Britain leaves the European Union by means of her proposed new EU security treaty. The most infamous of these is the evil European arrest warrant whereby any British citizen can be carted off to a foreign jail purely on the strength of allegations on a sheet of paper. Instead of retaining these legal instruments and institutions, the UK should repeal them all when we leave the European Union.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, this report refers to the implementation by the Member States of the European protection decision system. It involves applying a measure of expulsion, a ban on visiting certain places or a ban on approaching the victim within a certain distance for a criminal perpetrator throughout the Union. On paper, this could be a very good thing since this system should effectively protect a victim from further aggression. However, implementation becomes complicated, if not impossible because of the reality of a European Union of 28. Implementation is complicated, because we must necessarily change the laws of several Member States, without undermining the principle of subsidiarity and without doing so through sanctions that are and would be counterproductive for the women we need to protect. Implementation is impossible, since monitoring the whereabouts of an aggressor in a borderless area as large as Schengen would require considerable resources and perfect cooperation from the police and legal services of the Member States. How can we claim to be able to protect women, children, the weakest, when a terrorist is able to cross three states after committing a deadly attack? How do you want to protect a woman who is victims of violence when entire neighborhoods of our cities become non-legal areas for women? This system of protection that already exists in the Member States is a good thing, but the limits to which you yourself have forced it in a Europe without borders make it inoperative. Let us regain pragmatism and common sense, and the cause of women and their protection could then become one of the priorities for cooperation of European nations.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! First of all, I congratulate the rapporteurs, Theresa Jiménez and Mrs Soraya Post, now on this very good report, which makes specific recommendations for the European Protection Order. This is an instrument that fits into international efforts to counter violence and protect victims. We know that this violence is a worldwide scourge that affects virtually every state and that the victims are primarily women. We also know that this instrument, even though we have had great hopes in it, remains facade because only seven times it has been applied, even though thousands of women in Europe are affected by violence every year, lose health or life. The flaws in this instrument have been identified by the authors and I appeal to the Commissioner to implement it. First of all, this European registry, causing this order to actually be European and fulfill the functions that were intended to it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the European Protection Order was an initiative of the Spanish Presidency in 2010, which deserves recognition, as is the work of our two colleagues in the European Parliament who bring this debate on its implementation and its effectiveness, which is what it is all about. The European Protection Order has one objective: to protect victims and to enable such protection to accompany them in their movements within the area of free movement of persons. It is especially targeted at particularly vulnerable victims such as women victims of gender-based violence and victims of terrorism, but not only. But the basis on mutual trust and mutual recognition of judgments is essential, which is the feature that it shares with the euroorder, and which is not designed for judges to examine the quality of the requirement, but for them, on the basis of trust, to enforce it. This is how the message can reach its recipients, who are particularly vulnerable victims. That is why the European Union must ratify the Istanbul Convention but, at the same time, overcome this application deficit, which shows that there have been only seven European protection orders so far — four of them in Spain. We need to redouble our efforts to pursue the useful effect and effectiveness of the European protection order.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, Commissioner. I would like to thank my colleagues Teresa and Soraya for the work done by all of us who have participated in the drafting of this report. We are united by a common objective: to propose effective measures to ensure that a basic European initiative to combat gender-based violence is better known, used more, does not generate administrative or economic costs for its beneficiaries, adequately protect minors victimized by this scourge and promote harmonization of treatment the legal nature of gender-based violence in the Union. The limited dissemination of the possibilities afforded by this legal instrument is at the root of its very little use, despite the brutal impact of gender-based violence on women in the Union. It is therefore urgent to launch information and training campaigns aimed especially at legal operators and public services that come into contact with this problem. We have also proposed that host States inform protected persons of the social and health services that supplement EPO benefits. Unifying forms, digitizing processes, establishing specific processing deadlines and improving statistics are other proposals to improve the effectiveness and possibilities of use of the order.

name: Lara COMI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I also strongly thank both Soraya and Teresa, our rapporteurs. I think that this is a complicated and difficult speech for me today, because I do not speak as a parliamentarian but I speak as a woman, a woman who has suffered psychological violence, because we talk about violence not only physical but also psychological. And I myself speak on behalf of many women who have benefited from a non-approaching measure of the person, whose validity, however, is limited to the country of residence alone. Then the European protection order should be automatic: why do you have to make an additional request? When a State — Italian, France, Germany — makes a non-approach measure, this must apply all over Europe automatically; why should further requests be made? Secondly, women need to continue reporting. Because that's the problem: women don't report and don't recognize what is actually violence, because they let it pass. So I am convinced that an even stronger communication and knowledge approach is needed. Here at European level we can do it, as we have to do it in every Member State, and I conclude by saying that yes, there is the internal market, there is free movement of people, but we must also work on European protection order.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, protecting women from violence is our not only legal, but also moral obligation. The European Protection Order is an important mechanism in meeting this obligation because we live in a time of enhanced mobility. There are a number of measures by which implementation can be improved. Some recommend this Report: simplification of procedures, reducing red tape, uniform patterns, better informing officers and victims, and using new technologies. Unfortunately, the Report doesn't just deal with technical solutions, it is a big deal in the value sphere, so we come across claims such as the one about deep-rooted misogyny and sexism in our societies, with which many citizens, experts and us present here will not agree. Intervention in school curriculums is also recommended, which is completely outside the jurisdiction of this home. We all want to protect women from violence and that is why from these reports, which seek broad consensus, every ideology should be thrown out.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the report's primary data are minimal and inadequate. It is impossible to draw qualitative conclusions from the 7 registered European protection orders. Without data, safe questions, recommendations or evaluations are not formed. Moreover, the report bias insofar as it suggests that national protection orders are inherently inferior, while it does not conceal that protection orders concern only women but anyone who needs protection. Cross-border cooperation in civil and criminal matters must be designed with a view to protecting victims, punishing perpetrators and preventing additional offences. But fundamental rights and basic rules of ethical order act as a prerequisites for control of Member States through excessive requirements for systematization and reciprocity mechanisms, even in areas under the competence of the Member States. Recognition of a judicial instrument issued in one Member State and executed in another must go beyond the borders and interests of individual States and is one of the few cases of acceptable European integration.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, freedom of movement in the EU involves that people frequently move around from one country to another. This leads to many situations in which people in need of protection require EU-wide support. This is why it is essential to respect the right of victims and potential victims to enjoy freedom of movement on the same footing as everyone else and to ensure their continued protection when moving. Sadly, until now the use of the EPO has been underwhelming in this sense.  However, this report usefully identifies the main factors hampering its use, from lack of awareness among victims of the possibility of requesting it, to more general motives such as the reluctance of victims to take part in criminal proceedings. All these reasons must be dealt with to make this instrument an effective one in a modern world of high mobility without internal borders.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, today we will vote together on a report which, in fact, represents the evaluation of the implementation of the directive on the European Protection Order. Of course, I appreciate the work of my fellow rapporteurs and also the work of all my colleagues, because together we have worked in committee to make this report as good as possible in its final form. But the reality is that Europe is currently unable to provide, to know the exact number of European protection orders that have been requested, because there is no central European register of them, and most Member States do not provide this data. It is my opinion that we will not be effective in this area unless we have a report, we will initiate a report amending the directive, because the directive, in reality, does not contain a clear definition of the European protection order. Criminal law is imperative, not interpretive. As long as we do not have clear and binding rules for Member States, the European Protection Order will be ineffective.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, gender violence is causing increased concern in the European Union since there is documented evidence that one in three women over the age of 15 in the Union has suffered physical or even sexual violence. At the same time, one in five women has been the victim of persistent surveillance, i.e. harassment. At the same time, other data show that over 100,000 women have been included in programmes to protect against gender violence. Yet what we see at European Union level is that the European Protection Order has only been implemented seven times, which means that first of all this measure is not known at European Union level. The Commission therefore needs to roll up its sleeves, help with awareness-raising campaigns, so that this important measure can be used to protect victims of gender violence.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I want to thank the House for this exchange of views. It is an extremely important issue and I thank the Members for all of their comments. My first point is that the victims of violence and harassment are particularly exposed to secondary victimisation. I agree that more needs to be done to ensure that victims, victims’ organisations and police are fully aware of the European Protection Order (EPO). Because there is a very strong link between the correct application of the Victims’ Rights Directive and the correct functioning of the EPO. We have to stay on course and we must use all means available to ensure the proper implementation of the EU legislation in this field. I particularly want to thank this Parliament for its steady support in the process of the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention. I can assure you that we will continue our efforts on a few things: first, awareness-raising among practitioners and then the proper information to victims. I agree with you that the number of EPOs issued – seven – is really very few.

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I just wanted to add that I think the EU and the Member States have trivialised the fact of violation of women across Europe, and this is why I strongly advance and push for the fact that in the former EU security agenda there was a sentence on violence against women – for this mandate there was not. And I strongly recommend that it should be put in again. Because if we want to eradicate violence against women using the tool proposed – and of course the Istanbul Convention is one tool, the EPO is another tool – but I also strongly believe that to have it in our security agenda shows that we really take it seriously, and so much has to be done.  The #MeToo movement also showed us the trivialisation of sexual harassment and violence towards women. And so many women on a daily basis feel fear and threatened.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, contrary to what some of my colleagues — fortunately few — have said here, I do believe in judicial cooperation, I do believe in a European area of protection, where people can feel free and safe, Mr Synadinos. We do talk about all the victims. This report speaks of victims of terrorism, but, unfortunately, most protection orders are women, because they are gender-based violence. But we talk about all victims, because all victims are equal and deserve the same protection. And I think that if this law is well explained, it is well disseminated, it applies well, it can work, but it is not a matter of clarity, that another of our colleagues — a colleague — has said is unclear and is not defined. No, it is not a matter of clarity: it is a question of political will; and not only of the political will of this Parliament, nor of the Commission, but of the political will of parliamentarians who sit here and do not believe in Europe and do not believe in an area of freedom, security and justice, in which I and thank God most of my Colleagues, we do believe.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. — The European Protection Order (EPO) was promoted under the Spanish Presidency of the EU in 2010. EPO is a European legal instrument for victims of crime and although it is not limited to victims of gender-based violence, it is important to note that they are at the centre of their concern. The importance of action at Union level to strengthen the rights and protection of victims of crime should be stressed in this debate. The aim is to grant the victim of a crime in a Member State which was moving to a different Member State, the same or equivalent level of protection as he or she enjoyed in the former. This Directive was the first mutual recognition instrument within the EU aimed at victims and with a criminal nature. Any protection order issued in one Member State must be recognised and enforced in another Member State. OPE has the potential to be an effective tool to protect victims in a world characterized by high mobility, but more information is needed because it is currently underutilized.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. — Since the entry into force of this Directive, any European victim has the right to seek protection in another European Union country, whether he moves there permanently or if it is a temporary trip. Free movement of people in the EU means that people must be able to move freely from one country to another. EPO must ensure that every victim can move freely, while at the same time safeguarding their rights and freedoms. We must work towards ensuring that the protection of victims is not hampered by the diversity of national measures. In this regard, in the report we intend to adopt today we analyse these problems in order to find possible solutions. We aspire to make the EU area of freedom, security and justice a reality. If we continue to make progress in the integration process, and if we are fully committed to the free movement of persons, it is essential that we encourage such instruments based on mutual recognition. Recognition based on mutual trust and respect for the rule of law of the various Member States.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - Today we are discussing an important report. Many Member States of the European Union do not have registration systems to collect data on European protection orders. There is also no central system for recording important data in Europe. Insufficient data hampers the evaluation of the implementation of the European Protection Order and makes it difficult to overcome the shortcomings of the legislation. This issue is very important because the European Protection Order can cover victims of various types of crime, including terrorism, trafficking in human beings, sexual violence and organised crime. As regards applications for a European protection order, special attention should be paid to victims of serious crime. The European Protection Order can be an effective means of protecting victims in the modern world, which is characterised by high mobility and a shortage of internal borders. Member States of the European Union should be encouraged to disseminate information to people with protection about additional support measures in the host country, such as family or accommodation allowances, as these measures do not fall within the scope of the European Protection Order. Therefore, great responsibility in this matter lies with the state in which there is a person with special protection. We should also remember that special attention should be paid to children who become victims of crimes.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. — As has been reiterated throughout the previous work, there are serious gaps in the current Directive, which can be summarized in poor coordination and communication between Member States, the existence of situations of lack of access to justice and legal aid to victims and the scarcity of resources for sensitization and protection of victims (especially in rural areas). Therefore, we are facing a powerful judicial tool but which has proved to be ineffective today. This report calls on the Commission to get to work as soon as possible, and that is why my group will support this report. Finally, I would like to recall that the European Protection Order must serve to protect all victims, in particular women victims of gender-based violence, who are the greatest demand for this measure and who need it to be effective right now. We cannot wait any longer and the Commission must redouble its efforts on the new proposal. We will also continue to insist that it also revise its minimum programme and implement a genuine comprehensive gender strategy, with increased resource support and coordination with States.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the implementation of the Bologna Process – state of play and follow-up by Petra Kammerevert (O-000020/2018 - B8-0014/2018).

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: author. — Madam President! In this House, we have recently discussed the future of our European project. The key to its development is intellectual, cultural, social and innovative enhancement — that is, in short, the construction of a Europe of knowledge. Education and higher education is a central role in the construction of knowledge Europe. The Bologna Process is a pillar already established in the Sorbonne Declaration of the European Area of Higher Education. Since the Bologna Declaration, or since 1999, a great deal has been done, both in the quality of education, in the aspect of mobility and in the aspect of recognition of diplomas and qualifications. Unfortunately, the level of implementation of the goals of the Bologna process varies widely between countries. The quality of this implementation is also important, because it affects both the reliability of the process and the actual execution of its assumptions. In very many countries, the Bologna process has been misinterpreted, in others there has been a mechanical division into first and second cycle studies, not caring about the programming content, in others it is considered that this is an imposed government initiative, not our common European project. Therefore, we refer the following questions to the Commission — firstly, does the Commission monitor the level of implementation of the Bologna objectives in each country? These most important objectives are the quality of education, reliable quality accreditation, recognition of qualifications and diplomas, the correctness of awarding famous ECTS credits, i.e. points recording student achievement, promotion of facilitating mobility of both students and staff, but also the promotion of continuing education at the academic level. We also ask how does the Commission assess the current state and level of the Bologna process? Our question is also whether the Commission has identified these factors that impede the effective and correct implementation of the process? Finally, how the Commission supports the Member States in proper implementation of the Bologna process? Signatories of the Bologna Declaration and ministers of signatory countries meet cyclically to summarize the achievements of the process on the one hand, and to set new objectives and new assumptions on the other hand. The last such conference was in 2015 in Yerevan. Then a message was issued with a very important message — strengthening the social dimension of the Bologna process, the inclusion of students with disabilities, the inclusion of people from disadvantaged backgrounds, the mobility programme that is the essence of this process. We have a question for the Commission, how does it assess the steps taken as a result of the Yerevan Communication? How much has been done in the social inclusion aspect of the Bologna process? In Yerevan was also accepted into the European Higher Education Area Belarus, but unfortunately the Belarus authorities have not fulfilled many commitments, nevertheless we expect Belarus to remain on the agenda of the European Higher Education Area and the possibility of lengthening road map for Belarus. There's another conference ahead in Paris. The European Commission is one of the signatories of the Bologna Declaration. So we ask what strategic objectives does the Commission have? What initiatives does he intend to take to strengthen the Bologna process? What about the area of higher education after 2020? What strategic objectives does the Commission set? We also ask — and we are very interested in — what is the link and relationship between the European Higher Education Area, the European Research Area and the European Educational Space heralded by the Commission? We are of the view, as the Committee on Culture and Education, that only complementary initiatives can build an attractive innovative Europe of knowledge.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this discussion, I’m very glad to be here to discuss the Bologna Process. This is the right moment, in light of the upcoming Bologna ministerial conference in in Paris on the 24th and 25th May. I hope to be able to address most of your questions in the limited time available; I will do my best. On the current state and the evolution of the Bologna process, much has been achieved in the last 20 years in its three 3 major commitments. First, the three-cycle Bachelor-Master-Doctorate system has been introduced. A common degree structure is one of the most significant achievement of the process. Second, there is a common standard for independent quality assurance in higher education, yet high education institutions should benefit even more from approaches offered by quality assurance agencies placed in other European countries, not only their own. And third, the European credit system is in use in most of the countries and has helped greatly for the contribution of diplomas and study periods abroad. These three commitments are key to build the trust which is necessary for learning mobility, cross-border academic cooperation and comparability of higher education systems. Based on these achievements, it is clear that the Bologna Process remains highly relevant, although we know that the implementation of some of the commitments is still uneven across its 48 member countries. And this is the main challenge for now. While the structures are to a large extent in place, though unevenly, we now need genuine implementation at the level of higher education institutions, which governance structures of the Bologna Process find difficult to reach. This is the main factor hindering affected implementation of the Bologna reforms. The Yerevan communiqué in 2015 therefore called on the Bologna countries to propose a method to improve the implementation of key Bologna reforms. The years since then have not been a period of radical change, but more of consolidation. We must use next month’s ministerial conference in Paris as an opportunity to stress the need for more even implementation of the Bologna commitments and to mobilise member countries and organisations to work together more closely In other words, the Commission wishes to provide support to those Bologna countries which lag behind in the implementation of the key commitments. In this context, the Commission supports the adoption of a new structured peer support process to ensure better implementation and monitoring of the reforms. Hopefully, the Bologna ministers will also commit to removing the remaining obstacles in their national legislation to cross-border quality assurance. Your question also addresses the issue of social inclusion, which is also extremely important in respect of refugees. Not enough Bologna countries have so far introduced measures to improve the conditions for under-represented and disadvantaged groups to access and to complete higher education. The first step to foster inclusion and improve equity is to collect information on the participation of under-represented groups in higher education. Only systemic monitoring can provide evidence on the effectiveness of those measures. For refugees, some countries have specific recognition procedures in place. Activities built on Erasmus+ funded projects for national academic recognition and information centres, which will improve the consistency of decision-making. The Commission has also organised several peer learning activities for Member States to share experience and good practice. The next question, on our assistance to countries in their progress towards the Bologna commitments: we offer support at EU level, for instance within the Erasmus+ programme where we have a targeted call for this purpose. We also assist the Bologna Process countries that are not part of the Erasmus+ programme. They benefit from capacity-building projects, which the Commission wishes to intensify in the next phase of the process. They are a key feature of the Bologna Process. And it is in the EU interest that a less developed system can evolve. You asked how the Commission monitors the recognition of the qualification. We have to admit that this is difficult to assess, as it is usually higher education institutions which take those recognition decisions. But aside from the Bologna Process implementation report, the Commission also carries out studies to identify obstacles, areas for improvement and best practices in recognition of qualifications and study periods. For example in 2016. There was a study on obstacles to recognition of skills and qualifications. Finally, in terms of giving strategic guidance to the future Bologna Process, the Commission’s recent initiative towards the creation of the European education area is really essential. The main purpose of the European education area is to give a strong boost to learning mobility, to create a Europe in which learning, studying and doing research would not be hampered by borders so as to have a continent where spending time in another Member States to study, to learn and to work, has become the standard. In addition to expanding learning mobility, this ambition requires a number of concrete policy initiatives. I will mention four of them. First, the proposed networks of European universities will act as role models for the implementation of the innovation in teaching and learning, and for the efficient implementation of the Bologna instruments. They will be instrumental to further develop and consolidate the European higher education area and to build synergies with the European research area. Second, the planned Council’s recommendation for automatic recognition of higher and upper-secondary educational qualifications and learning periods abroad will give new impetus to the implementation of one of the three key commitments of the Bologna Process and will further expand learning mobility. Third, the new EU student card will facilitate both mobility and the recognition process. And fourth, an upcoming recommendation will help ensure that in addition to their mother tongue, young Europeans speak two other languages. Language knowledge is a pre-requisite for learning mobility. Thanks to the European education area, we will be able to advance faster among the European Union Member States, then among all of the 48 Bologna countries. But at the same time, it is clear that the European education area indicates the direction to follow and will give new impetus also to the Bologna Process. In this context, the Commission fully agrees with the European Parliament’s call for synergies between those three areas: the European educational area, the European research area and European higher education area. It is expected that in Paris, Bologna ministers will build on this new momentum.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank rapporteur Krystyna Łybacka. I believe that at the Ministerial Conference in Paris, the first objective, let us remember, the Bologna process, which today involves the universities of 48 countries, is that any student enrolled in a European university have the right to graduate and see its title recognised throughout Europe. But above all, we know that the process underpins the construction of this European area of higher education and the realisation of the Europe of knowledge. However, after 19 years, we have to point out some priorities and I am pleased to collect some of the proposals that have now been suggested to the Commissioner, because some of them go along these lines. I believe that the first point is to improve cooperation between the European Higher Education and Research Area. I believe that the inclusion of doctorates in the Bologna process is a very advanced element, the main link that will also push towards internationalization and strengthening partnerships. However, it also serves a phase of developing the quality of the processes and also the development of the European Higher Education Area, enhancing the social dimension of higher education. I am pleased that the e-card has finally been mentioned as a tool which, I hope, will be financed in the next multiannual programme and, in particular, I believe that we also ask for joint degrees, as well as to fund European universities. I think this is the step forward to take.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Commissioner! The Bologna process has undoubtedly a number of positive sides, but it is important not to be limited to celebration only and reflect on whether certain original assumptions were indeed quite accurate. After all, representatives of the academic world and researchers analyzing transformations in the field of education have long been alarming that there is a lack of reflection on the side effects of the Bologna process. Numerous publications on the subject include writings such as Teaching in Higher Education and the European Higher Education News Bulletin. I feel that here, in the European Parliament, we do not accept them. Critics of the Bologna process like the British sociologist Stephen Ball point out, among others, that by imposing rigid indicators and standards, academic teaching is judged only by the technical level of performance rather than intellectual values, creative ideas, shaping the personalities of students. This is negatively reflected on the content of the subjects taught, the professional autonomy of teachers and academic freedom suffers. Hence my question to the Commission: whether and in what measure its experts are examining these critical voices. Are the conclusions of critics such as Stephen Ball, Stefan Kuhl, Marvin Lazerson and many others considered? (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. — Mr. Professor! Would you agree with the view that these critical voices you cited testify to what I was talking about — that not everywhere the idea is understood, because the idea of Bologna is not standardization, but convergence with all respect and autonomy and programmatic freedom of individual universities?

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — It is also not my intention, that was not the point of my statement to stop or inhibit the Bologna process. I was merely pointing out that we should indeed think more deeply about the assumptions themselves, namely the negative side of this process is standardization. Perhaps, of course, it is mainly a matter of implementing this process, but in my opinion, we should consider certain assumptions, since especially the social sciences and humanities have their own specificity, which was not included in this process.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are proposing an oral question on the Bologna Process, with which we call on the Commission to act to reduce the gap between the grandiiloquent statements made during the ministerial summits and the concrete actions taken at Member State level members. I consider it very important that the resolution associated with our question emphasises the dissemination of knowledge, research and science as key to the Union's strategy and the promotion of European citizenship. However, I wonder to what extent we can say that we have developed the European Higher Education Area in a truly integrated way. As a Catalan and Spanish Member, I would like to draw attention to the inconsistency that my country is part of a European academic system, based on mobility and dialogue between students from different nations, while the central government cannot guarantee the right of citizens of Catalonia to study in the common language of the Spaniards. Weeks ago, the Minister of Education announced changes to allow parents to choose the teaching of Spanish as a vehicle language for their children in Catalan public schools. However, unfortunately, the Resolution that includes the enrolment rules for the next year does not contain any alternative to the Catalan language. At the very least, it is irregular that in a Spanish region public education does not allow teaching in the common language of all Spaniards, and especially within a European area that especially values the exchange of knowledge in different languages.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I found Mr Krasnodębski's opinion too negative. My majority of interests and that of the Committee on Culture and Education is to strengthen the European Higher Education Area. It is about European spirit, especially given the nationalist tendencies and doubts about the European project, and Bologna is a deeply positive European process. It's about a common higher education room. This is exactly what we want to achieve for our young people. Why are we discussing this today? The Bologna Process Ministers' Conference will take place in Paris in May, and we want this process to be enhanced and that there will be greater political commitment from the participating countries. In particular, both in the next medium-term financial framework and in the Member States' education budgets, we call for a significant increase in the opportunities for the development of our young people. Above all, we want to simplify and better recognise diplomas.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it should be remembered more often that education is a human right, it serves to train citizens and not ants to be included in a society hierarchical. The basic approach of the Bologna process, which also cancels many positive aspects of it, is precisely this: to want to bend European school systems with their differences to the needs of a market in the skewed work instead of creating European citizenship. There are so many things that should be changed. There is one, in our opinion, particularly urgent, that we proposed in an amendment, namely the exclusion of education expenditure from calculating the public deficit within the Stability Pact. Austerity policies have created a divided Europe, are unpopular and are one of the main causes of the Union's identity and consensus crisis. The cuts in public education imposed by austerity are set to produce an even more unbalanced and intolerable Union for future generations. You have to intervene in this field right away.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the Bologna Process is a form of European cooperation that suits the British attitude to Europe very well. It’s voluntary, inter-governmental, focusing on a single sector and has the sensible aim of making higher educational qualifications easier to compare across countries without lurching into a mania for rigid standardisation. In short, it’s not run by the EU and is all the better for that. This could be the way forward in so many areas. We could reinvigorate and modernise NATO, rather than seeking to create an EU army. We could allow countries to decide their own immigration rules without compulsory EU freedom of movement. But instead the EU always seeks to tighten its grip in pursuit of ever-closer union. It’s this attitude which led to Britain’s vote to leave and which will, I predict, lead longer term to a procession of departures in our slipstream.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, largely imitated abroad, the Bologna process has certainly enabled the compatibility of diplomas, nevertheless accelerating the brain drain within the European Union itself. The Bologna process has not been devoid of perverse effects. The lengthening and massification of higher education have been the pendants which have had the foreseeable result of a devaluation of diplomas. For cohorts of the sacrificed generation, stricken on mass unemployment reefs, diplomas are no longer a guarantee against downgrading or poverty. It is against this backdrop that the insistence on the inclusion of refugees is like a real camouflet for millions of young Europeans who will be the big losers of opening up academic programmes, since some, such as Erasmus+, are already suffering from insufficient funding. With this proposal, the European Union reveals its true nature implied by a systematic foreign preference in defiance of the aspirations of its peoples. There are indeed a need for budget increases, but it is better to use them well.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague Łybacka and others who have prepared this report, which may also be an important starting point for the ministerial meeting in Paris. The Bologna process is one of the few pan-European programmes and we can criticise it for some cumbersome or for some undesirable pageant phenomena. It is actually a collaboration of 48 different countries at an intergovernmental level, and it also needs to be known that it is carried out in an academically independent environment under variable political conditions. And in this situation, of course, the process is slow, but it also depends on how it is conducted by independent universities. And I think that's right. At EU level, we have Erasmus+ creating a common study area, and we want the Bologna process to be carried out within this Common European Area. So thank my colleagues and I believe that for a conference of ministers this is a good handout.

name: Milan ZVER
text: — Thank you also from my part to Mrs. Łybacki for the prepared question. The fact is that almost all of us agree that Bologna reform needs to go forward, that the process needs to continue, because only this is how the European Union will come in higher education to the so-called third generation of universities, the new generation of universities we urgently need. Although we all know that the charm of the old Humboldt University is still very much alive, it has support among the work of students and professors, but nevertheless the dynamics of development force us to make universities much more — today — vital and more excellent. Of course, we can not be completely satisfied with the process itself. The many places were understood more as a technical process, less than a substantive process. Not much attention was paid to the change of the curriculum, approaches and so on. But we need to realise that this is the right way to go. Only in this way will European universities come among the most outstanding in the world.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the convergence process of the various systems of European institutions is crucial for the construction of a Europe of knowledge and for increasing competitiveness international community citizens. The raising of quality assumes that the student is placed at the centre, giving the right importance to the social dimension of education, fostering the inclusion of people with disabilities, refugees and other vulnerable groups, as well as improving equality in education. Mobility should be ensured to groups of less well-off students and the adoption of a harmonised system resulting in mutual recognition of qualifications to allow their spending even in a country other than the one of origin. The European education area faces difficult challenges: an economic and social crisis not yet resolved, dramatic levels of unemployment and increasing marginalization of young people. The forthcoming Paris Ministerial Conference on the European Higher Education Area is an opportunity not to be missed to identify the remaining obstacles and possible solutions to support countries in delay.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, issues of education are the exclusive competence of the Member States, that is for granted. But what happened to the Bologna Process? From above, changes in education systems have been imposed as a compulsory so-called policy, because that is the process of functioning Bologna, because the United Kingdom has three years of higher education studies and because that is what they want to impose on the other States. Member States, in other words that the quality of university studies should be reduced, because there is a concept, through the Bologna system, to see education as a commodity rather than a public good. I conclude that it is sensible to have cooperation and coordination, but only on condition that the Member States retain their powers and decide under what conditions to enter the cooperation process.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Ms Łybacka for putting this oral question today. In past years the Bologna Process has achieved a greater transparency. It has made information about the European higher education area easily accessible and has increased the quality of education mobility and academic recognition. For all that, I strongly support the implementation of the Bologna Process, but we are all aware that despite all the achievements, some areas still need development. We should focus on stronger cooperation in order to achieve common goals in relation to the European higher education area, especially developing appropriate legislative frameworks for consultation on its development and creating opportunities for all mobility to ensure the largest possible numbers of students are involved. At the same time, it is important that participating countries facilitate the recognition of academic study periods and credits gained abroad

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: Madam President, ten years later, the fruits reaped by European convergence are quite uneven. A decade ago, the student movement said that it did not want education to become a school of elites or a factory for precarious people and, today, tuition is much more expensive, the quality of education has not improved, the door has been opened to private companies in universities, and there are teachers charging salaries for four hundred euros. European convergence promised to take better means, but it seems that they never arrived. It is true that the Bologna Process has brought us closer to Europe, but it was rather because studying a master's degree in Spain is so expensive that many students end up leaving abroad. We do need a European convergence, but another: convergence to bet on public education, public prices and an accessible university; convergence to bet on research and not turn the scientific career into a disparity towards precariousness; to build a society where the qualifications; and a gender-equal university.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, 20 years of Bologna Process with a consistent strategy of the European Union and the 48 governments of the Single Area, studies tailored to the needs of capital for a cheap workforce, lifelong mobility from country to country, institution to institution, opportunity collectors dispersed qualifications and skills, categorized degrees and graduates at different levels and then work wandering and uncertainty in the name of competition. The mill of the University of the market grinds all the same as that of West Attica in Greece by the government of SYRIZA-ANEL. In the name of removing existing barriers between different levels of education, different departments and degrees are envisaged and non-formal and informal education, intended for the many, students from disadvantaged environments, as clearly stated in the resolution. The answer is: all knowledge in the degree and this is the only prerequisite for full access to the profession, studies for all free without hindrance and discrimination, post-graduate research programmes leading to a PhD. Unified higher education with the people in power! (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Lara COMI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that our young people are the people who believe most in the European Union and that is why we must certainly facilitate harmonisation of the system school, both for the higher level but also for universities. The recognition of professional qualifications is right, but there must also be harmonisation of the programme, because the guidelines must be at European level; national differentiation is right but also the years of study, because for the same qualification we have a totally different period of study in the different Member States and this must be absolutely harmonised. On the other hand, the so-called Erasmus generation is aiming a lot on us, staking a lot on the future to make them more and more European, and also for languages it is a great investment. For example, in Italy, this should already start even a long time before junior high schools. So this is a very good initiative and we need to continue along that line.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am glad that we are having this debate before the May meeting in Paris. It is very clear that the Bologna Process has brought positive effects. We know well that education is the foundation, after all, of democracy, and I think, yes, the Commission must answer the questions posed here. We want this process to improve, because if we have a labour mobility, we also need to have a mobility of education, of students, we need to have this exchange of experience, but I think it can be streamlined, there should be fairness, also to address people with disabilities, to have the possibility for poor people to study and, as my colleague said, to be able to have a standardisation of qualifications, a situation that allows those studying and accessing the Bologna Process to be employed in different places in Europe. We look forward to the Commission's response.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! We must remember that the Bologna system is not just European Union states. These are also the countries that do not belong to this family, even as Belarus, which implements the Bologna criteria slowly, a little ineptly, but also shows that it has value. I want to stress that the Committee on Culture not only looks at these criteria, the Bologna system from its perspective, but we try to look at it critically too, from time to time paying attention to the cuffs. Whereas what is very important to me is also art schools. You have to remember that even in music schools you need these common foundations, common criteria, so that young people, who will then meet at a game in a particular orchestra, play on an identical basis, in an identical way. Whereas there is indeed a problem with art schools in visual arts, but I will point out immediately — the rectors of these schools understand this brilliantly.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I thank the House for this very interesting and very constructive discussion. Nobody denies that the Bologna Process has played a very crucial role in the last 20 years to build trust, both between the countries and between the higher education institutions, and this is really essential to promote cooperation and to promote learning mobility. For now, what is the most important for us and what will be our focus for the coming years? It must, and will, ensuring progress in implementing the Bologna Process. At the same time, we will continue to strengthen the capacity-building efforts for Bologna countries outside the EU, and we are trying to work with those countries that have still not fulfilled all of the obligations at this point. Let me refer shortly to Belarus. According to the assessment of the dedicated working group, although some limited progress has been made, the country does not meet the agreed requirements. There is a consensus that Belarus should join the new peer review process, which is foreseen for all 48 member countries, which aims to support the implementation of key Bologna commitments. It is, however, clear that it will also need specific support within the Bologna context to progress faster in this country. Last, but not least, the Commission sees the Bologna Process and the establishment of the European education area as complementary. We believe that the EU initiatives which we will take, within the context of the European education area, will provide a new, very much welcomed impetus to the Bologna Process. I will pass on all of your detailed questions and remarks to Commissioner Navracsics, but really thank you very much for this discussion.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. — There are still many aspects of the Bologna process that prevent the European Higher Education Area that so many concrete benefits would be able to achieve. Precisely for this reason it is essential that the countries participating in the Bologna process and the European Commission should endeavour to facilitate and make effective the mutual recognition of periods of study abroad and related credits, as well as qualifications acquired for academic or professional reasons. In addition, it is essential to provide and implement facilitative tools for disadvantaged students while supporting and encouraging the mobility of students, researchers, teachers and academic staff. Education and training are two fundamental aspects not only for the formation of citizens with the appropriate intellectual tools to participate consciously and critically in public life, but also to enable them to face the challenges posed by the world of work, adequately and without frustrating their aspirations. Ultimately, I am convinced that today, as never, it is essential to make massive public investment in education and training systems, especially in those states particularly battered by the crisis economic (I think so of the countries of southern Europe): only in this way will we in fact be able to give our young people a future.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. — Education is one of the main pillars of our society! Higher education plays an important role in fostering personal development and skills acquisition, increasing employability and competitiveness, strengthening civic engagement, active citizenship and cross-cultural understanding, promoting shared values and addressing challenges in today's world rapidly changing. The Bologna Process and the European Higher Education Area comprise 48 countries, among others, many of the EU's important neighbours and partners. They promote mobility and strengthen the international dimension of higher education. Partying countries need to increase political engagement and strengthen mutual cooperation in the implementation of jointly agreed objectives across the European Higher Education Area and, if necessary, develop appropriate legislative frameworks to consolidate the development of the Bologna Process, strengthen its credibility and to make this space an example of academic excellence in the world, as well as to increase mobility opportunities in order to participate in the highest possible number of students. The EU and Member States should make a strategy to increase their education budget to ensure free public higher education available to everyone, to encourage lifelong learning!

name: Romana TOMC
text: Written. — Our common goal once is to achieve the European Higher Education Area, because high quality higher education is essential for the development of a broad, advanced, knowledge-based society. The Bologna process promotes mobility, encourages and creates the foundations of excellent science, while respecting the principles of academic freedom and autonomy of institutions. We need to take care of great European universities by investing in content. But we should not forget about people. Students and students who will thus be a competitive counterpart from other world universities.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on five motions for resolutions on Belarus (2018/2661(RSP)).

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: author. — Madam President! It is not easy to be the chairman of such delegation as the Delegation for Relations with Belarus. This is moving between our expectations, our standards, our values and the realities that are functioning in Belarus. Today, by this resolution, we only relate, to the last four months, to what has been happening in Belarus, which must be of particular concern for us. This is the first local elections, the last in the cycle that have been held again, I stress again, not in accordance with OSCE directives. It worries us, it worries us, it upsets us. The second thing of great importance is all the time the attitude towards the Belarusian opposition: non-registration of opposition parties, numerous detentions, detentions, chicanating, also single activists. There is a lot of this, according to us completely unjustified, showing what standards unfortunately there should apply rather than apply. And the last element is also the one that is associated with such web portals as the Card, which have been closed, also without proper justification. That's what we're paying attention to.

name: Clare MOODY
text: author. – Madam President, this report makes clear that Parliament supports critical engagement, critical engagement based on concrete steps towards implementing full democracy and human rights in Belarus. We want to see a road map for EU-Belarus relations with clear benchmarks so progress can be measured effectively. We should continue to provide support and financing for human rights defenders and civil society organisations in the country, and we must condemn breaches of these basic principles as well as fostering people-to-people contacts. The EU is founded on the principles of freedom and democracy. We must be proud defenders of those principles at home and abroad. The people of Belarus have the right to expect us to deliver on these values for them.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Madam President, the difficult geopolitical location of Belarus does not legitimise the use of force and violent intimidation of its own society, including children. Here I would like to add one example, of the Charter 67 social network that was closed recently. It does not legitimise posing a direct military threat to its neighbours, such as the exercises in Zapad or environmental threats such as the Ostrovet nuclear power plant.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: Author. - Belarus receives constant attention of the European Parliament, but the situation in the country does not change. The same fundamental problems have been and remain unresolved. The last elections of self-government, so called, have been falsified for an ordinary time. OSCE, ODIHR recommendations are absolutely ignored, continued execution of death sentences (6 in recent years and these years), persecution and prohibition of independent media. Meanwhile, the European Union does not stop being mistaken in relations with Belarus. Two years ago, after the cancellation of part of the sanctions, an incorrect signal was sent to Minsk. In the negotiations on the priorities of the partnership, it is important not to make the same mistake, at least let us not repeat it. Relations with Belarus cannot be based solely on the willingness of some interested parties to provide microfinancial assistance or to develop trade. It is necessary to adhere to a strict policy of conditionality, to formulate our requirements clearly and, above all, not to forget about human rights and the threat of the unsafe Astravas nuclear power plant being built for the whole of Europe and Europeans.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
