text: Author. — The resolution mentions the Astravas Nuclear Power Plant, which, as we know, is built only 20 km from the external border of the European Union and is mainly planned to export electricity to the countries of the European Union, is a threat to all European citizens because it is being built in violation of international conventions and security requirements. Belarus must stop construction immediately and thus reduce its economic losses, because Europe will not buy electricity produced by it safely. My question to the Commission: We know that the stress test process does not assess the safety of the site. Is the Commission guaranteed that the chosen location is safe for the operation of the nuclear power plant?

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President! Dear ladies! I regret to say that two years after the lifting of sanctions against one hundred and seventy Belarusian citizens and three Belarusian entities as a result of the recognition of the steps taken by Belarus to improve relations with the European Union and its constructive role in the region, we return to situation in which violations of the rule of law and human rights occur in this country. Unfortunately Belarus has not carried out the expected reform of the electoral system all the time, while recent local elections have raised objections. I therefore believe that the Belarusian authorities should be strongly pressed to ensure that they respect the basis of democratic rule of law and fundamental human rights. At the same time, active support for Belarusian NGOs and independent media reporting information in Belarusian should be continued.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the release of political prisoners and the lifting of the majority of EU restrictive measures in 2016 were encouraging steps which paved the way towards the development of the EU-Belarus relations on a more positive agenda. However, I regret that no progress has been achieved in the field of electoral reform, in line with the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights and the Venice Commission recommendations. And unfortunately the local elections reconfirmed the shortcomings in law and practice. In light of these shortcomings, I share the opinion that the Belarusian authorities have to put forward a comprehensive reform of the election law and processes and to apply it before the next presidential elections. I also support the call for closer monitoring of the situation by the European External Action Service and the Commission and strict conditionality vis-à-vis the prospect of greater involvement of Belarus in Eastern Partnership policies, financial support and visa liberalisation. In order to ensure closer EU-Belarus relations the Belarusian Government has to bring forward clear reform commitments with regard to which setting up benchmarks and a timeline is necessary.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I want to support the motion for this resolution, because the main idea behind this proposal is that unfortunately the democratisation process in Belarus is not moving at all. Colleagues here very rightly cited specific cases of how municipal elections were rigged, how independent servers are banned, how it is very complicated, in principle impossible to establish an independent political party in Belarus. It is, in principle, the only dictatorship in Europe today, and we must respond, we must act, because if the protection of freedom and democracy is a fundamental idea, a fundamental European value, then we cannot be blind in this direction and we cannot tolerate these things in Belarus. So I agree with that, and now it is up to the EU institutions and the Commissioner, how they will comment on this at the European Commission to adapt our policy towards Belarus, adapt it to the fact that Belarus since 2016, no changes in democratization have been made.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner, it is no surprise that every 25 March demonstrations take place on the occasion of Independence Day. Nor is it no surprise that these demonstrations are repressed by arrests, not only preventive, but repressive, of international observers, human rights activists, journalists; because that is the practice under the regime chaired by Alexander Lukashenko. Belarus is a European country and, unfortunately, is an exception, the only country that has failed to make its way towards the Council of Europe, and the only country that maintains the death penalty. I therefore believe that the European Parliament has reason to worry about violations of fundamental rights, freedom of expression, information pluralism — of freedom, ultimately in a European country — and to exercise its full potential and diplomatic capacity so that Belarus is no longer an exception. In particular, there is a need to advocate for prestigious human rights NGOs, such as the Human Rights Centre “Viasna” and the Belarusian Helsinki Committee. Our work, as a continent free from the death penalty, will not be complete until Belarus is no longer an exception.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! This month — because, after all, it was only three and a half weeks — Belarus celebrated Freedom Day, and so the centenary of the proclamation of the Belarusian People's Republic. I think on this occasion we should all Belarusians give our heartfelt wishes, it is a shame that they have run out, and especially to the Belarusian National Front, which we owe such a wide scale of social participation in these celebrations, as well as to the Catholic Church, which strongly supported them. If we really want Belarus to have a future as an independent state, if we want it to reach a political order based on freedom, then first of all we must support language, historical sense, national sense. And so that national colours or language are not only the slogans of political and democratic speeches, but more and more deeply into social life, the reality of everyday life and public awareness. And such long-term work should be carried out by those who really are friends of Belarus.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the morning of 29 April 2016, during a peaceful protest for cyclists' rights, the Belarusian activist Dzmitry Paliyenka was arrested by the police. This 23-year-old boy is still in Babrujsk prison, sentenced to serve an unjust and unjustified sentence. He must spend ten days every month in solitary confinement, mail is not delivered to him, contacts with the outside are at a minimum and the few meetings with father and lawyer closely guarded. Like Dzmitry, so many other human rights activists and advocates are imprisoned and subjected to inhumane treatment. Their fault: carrying out their job, expressing an opinion. A situation that has lasted for twenty years and, despite Belarus having made timid progress in the Eastern Partnership, human rights continue to be trampled. We call on the Belarusian authorities to immediately and unconditionally put an end to the censorship of independent newspapers, the persecution of activists, bloggers and journalists, and, above all, to guaranteeing freedom and rights for Belarusian citizens and abolishing the unacceptable death penalty, a disgrace to the whole of Europe.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Mr President, cooperation with Belarus needs to be encouraged, but it needs to be supported if Belarus fulfils its promises, i.e. respect human rights. This is not taking place, and I want to give you one clear example. In Belarus for many years, Charter 97 worked. Charter 97 was a web portal that was blocked and stopped by Lukashenko and had to move abroad. For us, for Czechs and Slovaks, this is very important because the Belarusian Charter 97 was based on Charter 77, which our former President Vaclav Havel once helped build with us. We therefore, the Czech and Slovak delegations, approached Commissioner Hahn and Mrs Mogherini and informed them of this sad fact. I think it would be good for the Commission to address this.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, the Freedom Day on March 25 of this year was a celebration of independence, but is actually a kind of litmus test for the state of democracy in Belarus. I’m afraid that 2018 which has been the first year that Lukashenko has permitted such formal celebrations has provided no surprises. It was hoped that there might be a marked change in the government’s approach to the repression of its people, they still have the KGB, by the way. But reports have been made of opposition leaders, supporters and bloggers detained and the independent news website Charter 97 is still blocked. It seems that any promises made by Lukashenko to work towards a thriving democracy in Belarus are paper thin. Despite EU sanctions and multiple efforts to engage in human rights dialogue, no electoral reform has been attempted and the opposition media and NGOs continue to be oppressed by President Lukashenko’s regime. The door is ajar to constructive dialogue and cooperation but sanctions should remain in place from the EU until real progress is made for the Belarusian people.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, good morning. Honourable Members, thank you for putting this on the agenda: it is indeed important to talk about Belarus. EU-Belarus relations have come a long way in the last years. They continue to be driven, as many of you referred to, a policy of critical engagement from our side. We are very attentive, as you are – and thank you for that – to the human rights situation in the country. At the same time, we believe that progress in a variety of fields can be better achieved by means of enhanced cooperation. The release of remaining prisoners in August 2015 was a long-sought step which represented important progress in our relations. Since most of the restrictive measures were lifted in February 2016, EU-Belarus relations developed further. As for the commemoration of the 100th anniversary of Belarus Independence, the granting of official permissions by the authorities to hold a meeting and a concert on 25 March was recognised as a positive development. However, the preventive arrests and detentions that took place in the run-up to the commemoration were in contradiction with Belarus’ stated policy of democratisation and its international commitments. While far from being sufficient, in recent years Belarus has taken a number of encouraging steps. These include a pro-active participation in the Eastern Partnership; resumption of the EU-Belarus human rights and other sectoral dialogues; and the signature of the mobility partnership in October 2016. People-to-people contacts, including youth exchanges, will continue to be further encouraged through programmes such as EU Most, Erasmus+, Horizon 2020. Belarus has also played a constructive role in the conflict in and around Ukraine. We have recently observed an increased willingness by the Belarusian authorities to engage with the EU in the dialogue on human rights issues. That has been resumed upon Belarus’ initiative, and the next meeting will take place in June this year in Minsk. This increased willingness for debate has, unfortunately, not led to any measurable legislative improvements in the human rights situation in the country, notably also on the electoral framework that you referred to. We will therefore use the opportunity of the dialogue to reiterate again that democratic principles and fundamental freedoms of expression, assembly, association, including freedom of media (also online) must be fully insured. We will highlight again the need to resume as soon as possible the work on serious, comprehensive and inclusive reform of the electoral framework in line with OSCE commitments and other international standards, and we will continue to call for the introduction without delay of a moratorium on the death penalty and the need to strengthen the independence of the judiciary. There were a few questions by some of you on the Belarusian nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, and I will take this opportunity also to reiterate that nuclear safety issues are an overall EU concern, even more so when these facilities are being constructed on an EU border. Full transparency on the construction process and full cooperation with relevant international organisations, the EU and neighbouring countries are of utmost importance. The EU is using all four as an instrument that we have to address the construction in Ostrovets. The aim is, of course, to ensure that the highest possible safety standards are followed. The EU is, in particular, financing experts who are assisting the Belarusian national regulator during the construction of the power plant and through working with Belarus in the area of nuclear stress tests. Finally, honourable Members, we are now close to finalising the joint EU-Belarus partnership priorities, which will be the first document of this kind between the EU and Belarus – an important building block in our relations, setting the strategic frame for our cooperation in the coming years, in which human rights issues play a very important role. Our work in the biannual format of the EU-Belarus Coordination Group will allow us to monitor progress in our political relations and cooperation, and the fifth meeting is confirmed: it will take place next week in Minsk. The participation of representatives of civil society and experts in the discussions of the Coordination Group has become a standard feature, which is a positive development, and this confirms our support to, and the involvement of, the civil society, which will remain an essential part of our policy. The European Union is ready to assist Belarus in its reform efforts. Tangible steps taken by Belarus to respect universal fundamental freedom, rule of law and human rights will be key in shaping our future relationship with that country, and we will continue to closely observe action by Belarus with regard to freedom of expression and assembly, as well as securing a framework for a free and independent media, as we take forward a policy of critical engagement. We will, equally, continue to call for the Belarusian authorities to engage in constructive and open dialogue with the democratic opposition and civil society organisations to remove restrictions for political activities and ease procedures for registration for political parties and independent organisations in Belarus. Thank you all for putting this question on the agenda.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place after the debates are over. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Julia PITERA
text: in writing. — The European Union offers its neighbours multifaceted, far-reaching cooperation built on respect for common values such as democracy, human rights and the rule of law. In the case of Belarus, however, when rights and freedoms such as the right to life, freedom of speech or press simply do not exist, it is difficult to talk about respect for common values. Amnesty International 2017/2018 report reports that Belarusian courts, as the only one in Europe adjudicating the death penalty, issued further death sentences in 2018. In turn, according to the 2018 World Press Freedom Index compiled by the international NGO “Reporters Without borders”, Belarus ranks 155among 180 countries analyzed, assessed according to the degree of respect for freedom of the press. More than 100 journalists were arrested in 2017, and independent online news sites were blocked. Furthermore, no free and fair elections have been held in Belarus since 1994, and the country's government regularly refuses to accept the mandate of the UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Belarus. We, as Members sitting in the European Parliament, elected in free, equal and universal elections, with a duty to stand up to democratic values, should firmly oppose such actions by the Belarusian government by supporting independent sources of information, also those from abroad, and ongoing cooperation with civil society organisations and human rights advocates.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on six draft resolutions on the Philippines (2018/2662 (RSP)).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. — Mr President, I think repeating something here about the situation in the Philippines, that's like “wearing owl to Athens”. I think that anyone watching the situation in the Philippines knows that way about the increasing number of murders associated with the fight against illegal drugs. There were constant human rights violations, how the arrest of Senator Leila de Lima accused of alleged drug-related criminal offences, all the world's media reported. And the EU has long called for her release and ensuring a fair trial. The prosecutor of the international criminal court recently began a preliminary examination of the situation in the Philippines. Above all, we are concerned about the situation regarding the Philippine president and his statements that are directed against women. And we are also concerned about the increasingly frequent killing, violence, intimidation and harassment of people fighting for human rights, trade unionists, farmers and their family members. Ladies and gentlemen, we are seeing many murders in the Philippines in connection with the drug campaign. And that's why we have prepared a resolution today that calls on the Philippine government and all Philippine leaders to start seriously dealing with the situation and to try to make a real difference to the situation.

name: Neena GILL
text: author. – Mr President, when this House last adopted a resolution on the Philippines in March of last year 7 000 people had lost their lives in President Duterte’s cold-blooded war on drugs. A year on, the number has reached 12 000. How many more? Those who dare to criticise the Duterte regime face harassment, torture or arrest, this is the fate of activists, journalists and indigenous people. Or they’re simply banned from entering the country, as happened to my colleague Giacomo Filibeck, the Deputy Secretary-General of the Party of European Socialists, who was detained and expelled from the Philippines on Sunday while on his way to a political congress, because he had been critical in the earlier visit. This is not just an issue for my party. It means that many of our officials can be banned any time when it is vital to keep tabs on the situation, especially given President Duterte’s last month to withdrawal from the International Criminal Court. A point-blank confession that his war on drugs cannot withstand scrutiny. Business as usual, Commissioner, is longer an option. Having championed GSP+ for the Philippines, it is now time to review it.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, just over a year since our last resolution on the Philippines, the situation is, sadly, little changed. The self-styled strongman, President Duterte, continues to pursue his war on drugs – a campaign that is so far estimated to have cost the lives of over 12 000 people, many of them youngsters. Away from his headline-grabbing story, minorities including indigenous peoples continue to be marginalised and victims of human rights abuses. The news that the Philippines gave notice last month of withdrawal from the Rome Statute and the International Criminal Court is also of grave concern, and forms part of a wider pattern of authoritarian leaders across the globe quitting the International Criminal Court as an act of defiance against the international rules-based order. President Duterte’s comments urging other countries to do the same are particularly unwelcome. The intention to reintroduce the death penalty in the Philippines for drug offenses also raises grave concerns for the future direction of that country and illustrates that Duterte’s claims that he will continue in the same vein until his presidential term ends in 2022 are not empty threats. All taken together, the trajectory of human rights in the Philippines under President Duterte appears to be heading in only one direction, and that is not a very nice one.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, President Duterte’s war on drugs has taken the lives of around 12 000 people, including women and children. In addition to the killings and massive violation of human rights there is harassment of human rights defenders, critics of Duterte’s actions, indigenous peoples and so on, not to mention Duterte’s own unacceptable behaviour, with his remarks and calls for violence that amount to violation of international humanitarian law.  The threats, intimidation and violence must stop. It is extremely disappointing that the Philippines has decided to withdraw from the International Criminal Court. The reasons for this step are obvious. It is an attempt to avoid accountability for the crimes committed. The ICC initiative to inquire into this matter of crimes against humanity in the Philippines is highly welcome and needed, and all those responsible for the heinous crimes must be brought to justice.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. — Mr President. The Philippine President's call on its own police force to step up their attacks on human rights organisations is just one example of the rapidly deteriorating human rights situation. There is only an official list of about 600 people accused of membership in the New People's Army and declared terrorists. Human rights activists are also on this list. One of these is Victoria Tauli-Corpuz, the UN Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous. Many of the listed persons are afraid of being victims of extrajudicial killings. We welcome the fact that the Chief Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court has now launched a preliminary investigation to clarify whether the crimes of the war against drugs proclaimed by Duterte are to be considered as crimes against humanity. The EU must use all its means to exert pressure to correct this devastating policy. In this context, reports are worrying that future agreements with the Philippines should refrain from introducing human rights clauses. That would be a catastrophic false signal. I would ask you, Commissioner Malmström, to take this into account.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: author. — Mr President, with the so-called 'war on drugs', more than 12,000 people have been killed in the Philippines. Likewise, under the excuse of the war on terror, those who oppose the Government and extractive and agro-industrial projects are being attacked, murdered and criminalized. The Philippines is the Asian country where the most environmental defenders have been killed: forty-one in 2017; many of them in Mindanao, the country's mining capital. While the inhabitants of Mindanao denounce the enforcement of martial law, the persecution of indigenous social leaders accused of terrorism, human rights violations and the militarization of the region, multinationals — what a coincidence! — thank the Government for its protection. We demand that weapons and military equipment be stopped trading to the Philippines; that GSP+ trade preferences be eliminated and that current free trade negotiations be frozen. All our solidarity and support for the Filipino people and especially the people of Mindanao.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the situation in the Philippines is deeply troubling. The Philippines and the EU have a long-standing relationship in terms of diplomacy, economy, culture and policy. And indeed there is a long-standing relationship between my country Ireland and Philippines, for many Irish missionaries for centuries have gone to educate young Filipinos. So it is important that the EU provide its support to the government of the Philippines in restoring stability and respecting the rule of law. Through ratification of the partnership and cooperation agreement, the EU and the Philippines confirmed their joint commitment to the principles of good governance, democracy, the rule of law, the promotion of social and economic development and to peace and security in the region. I am particularly concerned, therefore, about the decision to withdraw from the Rome Statute, which deals with the four core international crimes of genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and the crime of aggression. This brings even more urgency to an already volatile situation, and I am hopeful that the Government of the Philippines will reconsider its actions and reverse its decisions.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, the situation in the Philippines is intolerable and tends to get worse and more. The Philippine Government has used several measures to silence civil society. One of the most used stratagems for this purpose is the criminalisation of NGOs and human rights defenders through laws that set too broad an understanding of terrorism. It was in the context of this type of legislation that the UN Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, Victoria Tauli-Corpuz, was included, together with several indigenous human rights defenders, on a list of organisations and persons allegedly responsible for terrorist activities. The inclusion of this special UN rapporteur calls into question her physical integrity, it could even jeopardise her own life. Last December, this rapporteur, Victoria Tauli-Corpuz, had made public statements of repudiation for Rodrigo Duterte's policies, namely the murders of members of indigenous communities in the south of the country, as well as the forced displacement of these communities to other regions. And it is worth remembering that 41 environmental rights defenders were murdered in 2017 in the Philippines. This situation is totally intolerable and the European Union cannot but have a say on this matter.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, who is responsible for a situation? Those who create it or those who try to fix it? This is also the case in our country, where thousands or even millions of immigrants are brought to areas that are already areas of trafficking, of non-law, where, in the end, behind poverty, there is also the regulation of crime. After decades of lax and corruption, the Philippines — which I know well — has become a country where drug addiction is endemic. Faced with a structured army of nearly 200,000 organized crime men, the president tries to restore the rule of law and save the population, 80% of whom are following him in his endeavour. Certainly, his methods shock me too, but no more than those of bombing Iraq and Libya, or inventing the Skripal case against Russia or finding chemical weapons to bomb against international law.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, it is interesting, but I think we that we should stay focused on the resolution on the Philippines. I know that we have another picture of the world, but the human rights situation in the Philippines is extremely alarming at the moment and has been so for quite a while. We are deeply concerned about the Deputy Secretary-General of the Party of European Socialists (PES), Giacomo Filibeck, who was arrested, along with many others, and not allowed to enter the country. So it is also shocking that human rights defenders, indigenous leaders, UN officials, and even national government officials, such as Senator de Lima, are being targeted by the Duterte Government. I strongly condemn the violent language also used by President Duterte about women. It seems that his war on drugs has also turned into a war against women. We cannot, I think, wait any longer. It is our obligation to take stronger action than before, even if this meant that we would have to reconsider GSP+ privileges.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! To begin with, I would like to protest against the view that has appeared in this room that the rule of law can be introduced by breaking the rule of law. This is not the way — this is merely justification for possible crimes. The second important thing for me is that we very often deal, precisely in the form of resolutions, with the affairs of remote states such as Venezuela, Colombia and today the Philippines. I'm interested to see if we have any “follow-up” of these activities of ours. I will immediately add that I am not in favor of not taking up these topics, but it is very important to me to prevent inflation in this matter as well as to try to make resolutions have an effect — not just preemptive, but factual. This is the question for Commissioner — to what extent do these resolutions help our external services?

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Mr President, indeed, despite many calls from the community, concerned about the increase in drug-related killings, Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte remains straight in his boots. Worse, it closes itself in a hostile attitude towards the International Criminal Court and allowed itself all regressions at the democratic level: willingness to re-establish the death penalty, multiple provocations against minorities, vexations against civil society, verbal attacks on women, even — you know — up to ask for their rape or murder! This is obviously unacceptable, which is why we must strongly demand an end to the abuses and remind the Philippine authorities of their international commitments. The exclusion of this State from the UN Human Rights Council before the end of its current mandate is one way, but other sanctions, particularly of an economic nature, could take place.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Mr President, drug traffickers must be hit within the framework of the rule of law, severe penalties must be imposed, and there must also be no release of drug traffickers from prisons under any pretext - because this is often the case. But in the Philippines the war on drugs has now become a liquidation operation conducted by the armed forces with over 20,000 victims and extrajudicial executions. At the same time, the President of the Philippines is taking this opportunity of war, as he says against drugs, to tackle his political opponents very hard and of course he is driving the Philippines into extreme situations with violence against women and the reintroduction of the death penalty. Therefore, measures must be taken against the Philippines, for example by abolishing the general tariff preferences of the European Union which now import duty-free Philippine products here in the European Union.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the climate of terror enveloping the Philippines has reached extremely worrying levels, which can no longer be tolerated. The tough war on drugs carried out by President Duterte is bringing with it an alarming number of victims who have fallen under the blows of police and mercenaries, too often in a summary way, without trial and without any plausible motivation. A president of a sovereign state that justifies rape, which encourages armed repression of activists and incites the killing of women cannot be ignored. Although the harsh crackdown on drug trafficking and the no-neighbourhood fight against organised crime are absolutely shareable battles, we are not discussing the end today but the methods. In fact, there is an appalling number of extrajudicial executions in the Philippines at the hands of police and mercenaries, masquerading as a drug operation. The expense is not the drug lords but, mainly, people of low social extraction from the poorest neighborhoods of Manila. I therefore believe it is necessary on our part to put all the pressure we can on President Duterte to bring an immediate end to extrajudicial executions and ensure due process to his long list of suspected terrorists.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr. President! The war on drugs in the Philippines raises a number of issues, which have already been pointed out by international organisations dealing with the protection of human rights. I would like to draw attention to two important aspects. One is the problem of the state monopoly of violence. Acting by means of violence is the responsibility of state bodies, especially the police, yet there is a lot of news in the Philippines that civilians will be vigilante and the public authorities will turn a blind eye to this phenomenon. This is an extremely dangerous and self-provocative process that is easily uncontrollable, but, of course, the citizens' right to security, which is also being defended by the police. The other problem is the lack of legal certainty. If anyone can decide without a court hearing who deserves to be punished or even death for drug abuse, then we are back to prehistoric times, although there were some rules in place. Point abuse, of course, occurs in all countries, unfortunately, but in the Philippines they seem to be making state policy out of this.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, “if they obstruct justice, shoot them!” , chilling words that chastening President Duterte was uttering last August, when instructing police on how to attack human rights defenders and anyone who got in the way of his cleanliness of the nation. Sadly current words: over ten thousand deaths, less than half allowed by police and justified with a reaction to arrest. Duterte's so-called drug fight continues undeterred; justice is constantly denied to thousands of innocents and their families; human rights abuses multiply disproportionably. There are few activists and journalists and also part of the political class to fight against this rampant violence. Leila De Lima has been illegally detained in Manila prison for 14 months: no trial, no evidence. We had already condemned his arrest. Today we must raise our voices and call on the government to release the senator immediately, not withdraw from the Rome statute and cooperate with the ICC investigations. The European Union must exert every possible pressure to ask the Philippines to fulfil its international obligations and President Duterte put an end to his genuine policy of terror.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the EU, we have expressed strong concerns about the various human rights issues in the Philippines on numerous occasions, both in bilateral meetings at political level with the government as well as in different statements. The issues that have been raised are the issues you raised here: the high number of killings associated with the campaign against illegal drugs, the climate of impunity, the declared withdrawal from the International Criminal Court, the possible reintroduction of the death penalty, as well as a possible lowering of the age for criminal responsibility to nine years. Further, the issue of the general situation of human rights defenders have been raised: the arrest of Senator De Lima and challenges to the freedom of expression and opinion as well as to the independence of institutions, including the impeachment procedures initiated against the chief justice. This has been raised in different declarations and statements by the EU28 Human Rights Council, the High Representative’s spokesperson and we addressed it in a very comprehensive way in the EU Special Incentive Arrangement for Sustainable Development and Good Governance (GSP+) monitoring report that I discussed here with you earlier this year. I have also personally met with Filipino representatives of government on numerous occasions where I have raised the concerns. We are closely monitoring development, especially now regarding the petition of 21 February by the Department of Justice, which includes a list of more than 600 individuals, alleging that they are members of the Communist Party and the New People’s Army. The list includes inter alia, the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the Rights of Indigenous People. We note that UN special rapporteurs are protected by specific diplomatic protocols during their United Nations-mandated work. Regarding all the individuals on the list, the EU expects the Government of the Philippines to fulfil, in all its proceedings on the matter, its obligation under national and international law, in particular, the respect of the rule of law and human rights, and to ensure their physical safety. That includes the right to due process, the independence of the judiciary and a fair trial for every individual. We are disturbed by the denial of entry into the Philippines and the subsequent forced deportation from the country of the PES Group Deputy Secretary-General Giacomo Filibeck. He was blacklisted for participating in supposed illegal political activities, where as you know and you also referred to, he was officially invited to attend the congress of Akbayan, an opposition party which is represented both in the Senate and in the House. We immediately raised the matter with the government, as this is the first case of a foreign-national and an EU citizen being expelled from the country for political reasons during the current administration. Human rights violations, including extrajudicial killings, and widespread impunity have been a long-standing problem in the Philippines, as highlighted in the GSP+ report. We remain convinced that both the Philippines and the EU have most to gain from constructive engagement. The partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and the Philippines entered into force on 1 March this year. And this agreement foresees the establishment of a structured human rights dialogue between the parties, which will be an important forum for addressing all human rights issues. The issue of the GSP+ commitment was raised by several of you, as you remember we discussed this in this plenary in January where we highlighted that indeed, there are several areas of progress by the Philippine Government when it comes to the work on gender equality health, education, social and economic rights, labour rights, fight against corruption, protection of the environment. However – and this was also very clear in the report – extra-judicial killings, especially in the fight against drugs-related impunity, and the possible reintroduction of the death penalty were mentioned. We also addressed recommendations to the Philippine Government and I have also personally conveyed them to the minister that they need to do more to address the issues we have discussed here. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this year’s GSP+ monitoring mission will focus on the issues related to the war on drugs. And the EU will assess recent developments before deciding on the next steps. You can count on the European Commission and on the External Action Service to continue raising these matters with the Philippine Government in a clear and constructive way.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place after the debates are over. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – President Duterte’s murderous ‘drug war’ entered its second year resulting in the killing of more than 12,000 drug suspects. Duterte has responded to increased criticism of his anti-drug campaign by impugning, harassing, and threatening critics of the government and human rights defenders. Under unclear circumstances and fabricated evidences Senator Leila M. de Lima has been put in jail while at the same time the UN Special Rapporteur, Ms Tauli-Corpuz, has been put in the terrorist list. Unfortunately, President Duterte’s rule looks more like an authoritarian regime rather than democracy. Under his term the principle of the rule of law has not been respected in Philippines and human rights have been constantly abused by the government. In this context, I call on the authorities of the Philippines to immediately stop the extrajudicial killings, to prosecute all perpetrators, to respect the rule of law and international human rights law. In addition, the EU must support the independent international investigation into the unlawful killings and other violations in the Philippines in the context of President Duterte’s actions. Last but not least, I call on the Philippines to remove UNSR Tauli-Corpuz from the terrorist list and to ensure that Senator Lima has the right to fair trial.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. — I have repeatedly stressed that the fundamental duty and function of the state is to properly, effectively safeguard the rights of its citizens and citizens and to create an environment conducive to the prosperity and development of society. I firmly believe that the Philippine authorities must take immediate measures to prevent the proliferation and use of drugs, mass killing of people, terrorism crimes, and to develop active international cooperation in the field of crime prevention. In my opinion, a policy of intimidation and oppression based on violence is not an appropriate and proportionate instrument for achieving the objectives of peace and prosperity in the Philippines. It is necessary to prevent the application of the death penalty, to ensure that justice can be pursued by peaceful, adequate means, guaranteeing the right of the person to defence, to a fair and impartial trial. Great attention must be paid to public health, to adequate treatment and to help socialize victims of crime and their relatives. It is also necessary to take action to improve the education and science system, to raise the social and economic level of society.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on six draft resolutions on the situation in Gaza (2018/2663 (RSP)).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: author. — (FR) Mr President, the text we are going to vote today, supported by the EPP, is balanced and clearly states a number of things. First of all, the report mentions that the protests in Gaza were orchestrated by Hamas, which is inscribed — it should be recalled — on the list of terrorist organisations in the European Union and has as its ultimate goal the destruction of Israel. Secondly, we recognize Israel's right to defend itself. We therefore strongly condemn Hamas's recurrent attacks on Israel, as well as the use of civilians as a shield. We also deplore, of course, the loss of life and wounded in recent protests and encourage restraint in the use of force. Our goal is, of course, to prevent an escalation of violence, but that is not what Hamas wants to seek confrontation and to divert the idea of non-violent protests to its own ends. I would also like to emphasize that the reaction of Palestinians in Gaza is significant, since a much smaller number than Hamas hoped participated in the demonstrations of the second week. This shows that Gazans are also protesting against their leaders, that the well-being of the population is not at all a concern of Hamas, which, instead of investing in education and health for the benefit of the population, finances tunnels of terror and rocket fire at Israel. It's completely stupid!

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: author. — Mr President. I only have a minute, unfortunately. What Mr Preda said cannot stop in the room like that. He sees only Hamas and says nothing about what the Israeli Defense Forces have done. Today we have 75 years of “the beginning of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising”, 70 years of independence of Israel, and at the same time 50 years of occupation of Palestine. When Israel celebrates its independence, it must be said that the international community supported Israel at the time. However, this also obliges Israel to stand by international law to respect human rights, and all that Israel is constantly doing during the status quo is a violation of human rights and international law. Last but not least, what happened in the Gaza Strip: deploying targeted snipers there, including killing three children, is a very brutal violation of human rights and international law. We must and will condemn this as a Parliament.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author. — (NL) Mr President, first of all I would like to thank colleagues, because yesterday we had difficult and difficult negotiations, but I am very proud of the result, the compromise before us today. After all, it is a compromise that we are going to support in unity, and it says in a very clear language, in unitary language, what we actually mean. We all condemn violence together, we call for an immediate cessation of violence. We also show in unity that we are not naive. Of course, we know the role of the terrorist organisation Hamas. We are also one in our resolution calling for an independent investigation. And yes, we welcome the fact that Israel is launching its own investigation, which we will also look at. I think this independent investigation into what really happened there is very important to me. We also give an important signal by calling for the end of the blockade. Because the humanitarian situation in Gaza is dramatic. That is why this resolution should really be a wake up call, the umpteenth.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: running. — Mr President! When Ghandi in his day set in motion his nonviolent resistance against the English, colonial power just shot loose on them. Many died. But Ghandi persisted. The violence of the English might have done so, too, were it not for a waking press from England, which reported home on the military crackdowns against the unarmed Inders. The protests rose up in England and the matter ended as familiar with the liberation of the Inders. Without the public attention, the violence against the inside probably could have just continued. We in the European Union have historical responsibility for the situation in Palestine, and we are the ones who now have the responsibility and duty to stop the dehumanisation of the Palestinians who have wisely chosen Ghandi's path, even with Hamas's support for non-violence. The joint motion for a resolution is not good! It is full of contradictions, even demonstrably false accusations as in paragraph 3, but it also holds important points, such as the condemnation of killings and injuries of unarmed civilians. There are calls for an immediate and unconditional end to blockade on Gaza and opening all passages and other important things. That's why most people in our group can vote for it.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Author. — (NL) Mr President, one recent image from the Gaza Strip has shocked me greatly and shocked me to this day. That was a scene with a coffin draped with the Israeli flag. On the side of the coffin were the pictures of two young Israeli soldiers. In one photo, I recognized the face of Hadar Goldin. Hadar Goldin was murdered by Hamas terrorists during a UN truce in 2014, and his body has still not been returned to the family. This goes against principles of international humanitarian law. I know Hadar Goldin's mother personally, Lea Goldin. One intense desire drives her: a worthy burial near home for a beloved, gifted child. The European Parliament is today adopting a resolution which clearly calls for the return of the bodies of Hadar Goldin and Oron Shaul to the families. I would like to underline these paragraphs and warmly welcome them. It is about the principles of respect for the life and dignity of the dead. It is my heart's wish that this resolution will help to restore the bodies and basic human dignity for the Goldin and Shaul families. The European Parliament is using this to gauze the souls of severely affected parents on both sides.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: author. — Mr President, since 30 March we have witnessed, once again, the criminal activity of the Israeli army. They attacked the civilian Palestinian people, painting the peaceful demonstrations with blood. 34 Palestinians were killed by the occupation army and thousands injured. This year marks eleven years since the inhumane outright blockade of Gaza began because of Israel's barbarism. Gaza is now an open prison in which 2 million people are crowded. We strongly condemn these blatant violations of the human rights of the Palestinians and demand that the criminal activity of Israel be put to an end and that Israel should finally commit itself to implementing the decisions of the International Community. We believe that the resolution proposed by many political groups is weightless. Unfortunately, in many places it equates the perpetrators, the murderous Israeli occupying army, with the victims, the Palestinians. That is why we cannot adopt this resolution. We call on the European Union to put an end to the unacceptable policy of equal distance.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — I will immediately add that I am not optimistic. It seems that a conflict that has gone on for so long, and which is made up of so many political, cultural, religious, military elements, cannot be resolved overnight. We are aware of that. What it can rejoice is that under this resolution, five main groups have signed up under this text, and so there is agreement to define the situation we are dealing with at the present time. I want to point out that what pleases us today in this room, which is this growing awareness of the Palestinian people, that the goal of Hamas is not peace, is not a truce, it is not an objective that is relevant from the point of view of resolving conflicts that have been happening there for many years, but may be a source of sure not so much satisfaction as a certain hope. And the last thing — the resolution arose in some pains. I am aware, having participated in the arrangements of the latter, that we are dealing with some compromise, but I will emphasise once again: the signing of five groups under this uniform text is a certain success.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, the truth is that the Socialist Group promoted this resolution and wanted to work with a broad consensus in this House. We found it very important that the resolution be supported by the maximum number of groups. The truth is that when I listen to Mr Preda, I cannot tell you how much I regret having finally made a compromise with the European People's Party. Things as they are: Gaza is the worst open-air prison in the world. That's the truth. What happens is that Mr. Preda's compassion reaches right into the Gaza Strip, there he no longer has compassion. Young people blocked for decades — decades — who have nothing at their fingertips — no water, no air, no ability to breathe, or feed, or heal — are being shot at the knees and ankles to leave them invalid for the rest of their lives. Yes, Israel has the right to its security, of course, and this Group will always condemn terrorism, but what is being done in Gaza is intolerable, inhuman, useless and very, very dangerous. And I would ask the People's Group, once a great agreement has been reached in this House in which we have all had to resign, not to make such utterly detrimental statements to the consensus of this House. We demand the immediate cessation of the blockade in Gaza. And we demand an independent investigation to judge what we believe has been a disproportionate use of force by the Israeli army against unarmed youth. That is the position of the Socialist Group and that is the position that this resolution defends.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, Of course, the resolution we negotiated yesterday represents a compromise. But this is a compromise that we, on the part of the ECR Group, have chosen to live with. We are pleased that it has been emphasised several times in the resolution that Hamas is a terrorist organization and that the Gaza Strip serves as the hub for international terrorism. We are also pleased that the resolution asks for the return of the bodies of the two Israelis who are being held back by Hamas in the Gaza Strip so that the two dead can have a dignified burial. Having said that, there is no doubt that the ECR Group stands firmly on the very clear view that terrorism must stop and that Israel has a right to defend itself and its borders. Until the day we find a political solution to the conflict, then you have to maintain that Israel has a sovereign right to defend its borders and to defend its territories both against the terrorist attacks that have come from Hamas and the Gaza Strip, but also completely generally from overflow.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (ES) Mr President, on 30 May and 9 April Israeli security forces opened fire on protesters in Gaza calling for the return of refugees and the end of the blockade: more than 30 deceased — three children; a journalist wearing a jacket accrediting himself; over 1,350 people were shot and Forty people still in critical condition. United Nations experts have pointed out that at no time did the demonstrators endanger the physical security of the Israeli forces. I would like to recall that the use of lethal force against demonstrators who do not pose a risk to life or physical integrity is contrary to international law — and specifically the Fourth Geneva Convention — and a crime under the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. Every State is obliged to respect peaceful protest and to intervene with the least necessary force. We condemn the murders; we demand an impartial investigation; we demand Israel to allow urgent medicines into Gaza. We call on the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court to immediately open an investigation, and we demand, once and for all, the end of this inhuman blockade to which the people of Gaza are subjected and that the United Nations is now pointing out that there are 1.3 million people in need of urgent humanitarian aid.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) (FR) Mr President, too many colleagues are reversing the situation. What is the phrase that Israel would have the right to defend its border? Israel does not even know its borders. On the other hand, it is Israel that occupies Palestine and makes Gaza an open-air prison that the United Nations has said would become unlivable by 2020 if nothing is done. Who, what consciousness here, what human consciousness can accept this? This country violates all chapters of international law as well as the letter and spirit of the association agreement we have with it. There were at least 40 people killed in Gaza, including children, peasants and journalists totally disarmed in a peaceful demonstration. The European Union itself must call for and expedite an independent commission of inquiry, establish a mechanism for the protection of the Palestinian people, lift the blockade of Gaza and stop the process of colonization of houses and evictions in Jerusalem. In the very name of international law, sanctions must now be imposed on the Israeli government.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current pattern of repression we are seeing in Gaza has reached dramatic levels which can no longer be ignored or justified from the international community. Over 30 people were killed in the two days of protest that took place in recent weeks, in addition to the approximately 2 000 who had already been injured. The Israeli army laid out sharpshooters along the border to fire on protesters trying to reach the fence that protects the border: but they actually opened fire on everyone, as witnessed by the dramatic images that have gone around the world. The response of the Israeli state proved entirely disproportionate in the face of protest rallies. I find it puzzling the justification given by the Israeli political and military authorities, that some of the wounded and deceased were members of Hamas and therefore constituted an immediate danger for Israel's security. Numerous NGOs and UN experts have considered that there were no serious threats to the safety of the Israeli security forces: the use of lethal munitions outside situations of serious danger constitutes a serious violation of international law and human rights. Ladies and gentlemen, I am delighted to see that the situation in the Gaza strip, which has been subjected to naval and maritime blockade by Israel and with 1.3 million people in a state of serious material deprivation, economic and health, is a blatant example of violation of the rule of law, certainly by Hamas but also and above all by those who consider themselves to be the only democracy in the Middle East and therefore should comply, for example, the Fourth Geneva Convention for the Protection of Civilians in Wartime.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: — Mr President, the State of Israel has been illegally occupying Palestinian territories for decades, denying international agreements, seizing new territories with settlements, expanding its borders daily to the detriment of Palestine, depriving Palestinians of food and water, oppressing, exile, imprisonment, murders unarmed demonstrators and children, as now in blocked Gaza, an open prison. That's why the protesters call it a killer state. It is the responsibility of those who equate the Palestinian victim to the Israeli perpetrator, backed the latter, seeking to forget - he says - the word 'resistance'. But remember that, without resistance, Europe today would still be Nazi. Americans, NATO, the European Union and governments such as SYRIZA are strengthening cooperation with this imperialist state in the Middle East and are bombing Syria with it, instead of all governments recognising the state of Palestine. But with the solidarity of the people and their own heroic struggle, we are confident that the Palestinian People will have their independent state, at the frontier of 67, with East Jerusalem as its capital.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Mr President, at huge risk of being judged anti-Semitic, I, as a Roma and Jewish person, dare to strongly criticise the Israeli government. Israel has to end the blockade and the closure of the Gaza Strip. The people living there are living without access to such basic needs as food, water, electricity and education. Recently we, as EU officials, went to Israel. We were not allowed to enter Gaza. We were in the West Bank, and what we did see there was an apartheid state system, with great humiliation as regards their basic human rights. There are currently 356 Palestinian children – children – in Israeli prisons. Now is the time for the EU to speed up the two-state solution. It is the only way to secure a peaceful, fair future for both of them, and I mean it. After being there and talking to Israeli and Palestinian officials, now is the time.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — The European Parliament must condemn the massacre carried out by Israel by murdering 30 peaceful protesters from Gaza and injuring 2 000, including women and children. The use of force against peaceful protesters, with disproportionate attacks by Israeli defence forces, can never, ever be justified for reasons of security. There are a lot of Zionists in this chamber, as we have just heard. The Palestinian people have a fundamental right to peaceful protest and free movement, including the return of refugees. We have to be clear: either we are on the side of violence or we are on the side of peace. Israel despises human life with total impunity. Military officers refused to cancel illegal open fire orders and the government continues to justify open fire. When a state attacks peaceful demonstrators with disproportionate force, it is a criminal state. What can you expect from a state that arrests minors like Ahed Tamini, that kills journalists, hurts children? We call for an end to the Gaza blockade and we want an independent and transparent inquiry. Not as the Minister of Defense said who has just denied this inquiry in Israel. We ask for an end to illegal occupation and apartheid.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Mr President, in the past few weeks thirty peaceful demonstrators have been killed and more than 3 000 injured by the Israeli army in Gaza. The killing of demonstrators is a very serious violation of the most basic rights and an intolerable practice of the Israeli army. So are other violations, such as the imprisonment of minors such as activist Tamimi. Palestine continued to live under a military occupation that practiced ethnic cleansing on a daily basis against its people. Enough words, ladies and gentlemen! If Israel refuses the independent investigation called for by Mogherini, the European Union must immediately suspend arms exports and any security and trade agreements with Israel. The European Union could not be an accomplice in the crimes of apartheid against the freedom and equality of Palestinians and Palestinians, against the rights of refugees, as denounced by the legitimate and peaceful BDS campaign and recognized by United Nations institutions. The European Union is obliged to act and punish Israel as South Africa and its apartheid had already been sanctioned. Long live the struggle of the Palestinian people!

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr President! The resolution itself is fundamentally balanced and reasonable, whereas my doubts make sense for Parliament to produce such a number of documents, because they are only international displays, because if you want to have real influence on the international stage, then you need to have a real impact on the international stage. tell you what they can give to someone and what they can threaten, and this document does not answer any of these questions. In this regard, there is only such instruction—you are so nervous, they rise, and no one, unfortunately, listens to it, because there must be specific pressure measures behind such actions. So I think that the momentum needs to be drawn to produce such a number of international resolutions because it leads to inflation of their importance and simply no one will care about them. On the merits — I think it's appropriate to avoid imposing democracy on all countries in the Middle East because it ended very badly in many cases.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the emotional debate that has been here, and let me make some comments. First, like most of my colleagues, I want to condemn the tragic incident on the Palestinian-Israeli border. On the other hand, I have to stand here for my colleague Predy, who has often been mentioned by our left-wing colleagues. I guess we don't agree on the description of the Israeli-Palestinian problem. We have clearly stated here, even a colleague of Preda said, that in short, it is impossible to take only the effect, the tragic incident, which we all condemn, but the activities of the terrorist Hamas movement carried out there, which contribute greatly to such incidents and contribute greatly to what is happening on the Israeli-Palestinian border. And that's good to say, the context is obvious here, and it's not possible to just state that there is a tragic effect.

name: Maria ARENA
text: — Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Preda that if he wants to do useful work in the fight against anti-Semitism, he can leave the ranks of the EPP Mr Orbán, who is the first European anti-Semitic and who has made irresponsible comments about the Jewish people. With regard to Gaza in particular, that territory has been the victim of three wars in less than six years, has been living under Israeli blockade for more than a decade. Gaza, 2 million Palestinians live on 300 km2 without being able to get out of it, without electricity or water, without education or jobs, it is a humanitarian disaster. That is what Palestinians living in Gaza are demonstrating against this, and the only Israeli response was to fire live ammunition at unarmed demonstrators. The reaction, once again Israeli, is neither legitimate nor acceptable, it is illegal. I would also like to pay tribute to Israeli civil society such as the NGO B'Tselem, which calls on Israeli soldiers not to shoot. I call on Europeans to be as brave as Israeli civil society and to impose sanctions against Israeli policies.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, first of all, we have to say that there is a Hamas designated terrorist organisation, and in here and by many others, there is a Hamas elected government by the Palestinians, so we have to accept it. How do you expect the situation, Commissioner, to be in the world's largest concentration camp? The Israeli occupation is the issue we have discussed more times in this Chamber, more than even the Syrian war. Tell us one measure you've taken - one not two - for the murders. Tell us an initiative you've taken to push Israel. Palestinian citizens are murdered by Israeli soldiers in cold blood and Lieberman hands them medals of honor. It states that it will wipe out the Palestinians and guarantees that there will be no consequences. It seems that for Mr Preda the Palestinians have been so dehumanized that they do not deserve a humanitarian intervention, their blood is cheap, their suffering is meaningless and their murderers may be your friends and partners. Every time you answer that there is no majority in the Council - how do you know? Did you propose it? I have made so many appeals to you to freeze the association agreement with Israel, you are obliged both by the Treaties and by the European Union and by the Agreement itself. If you don't change your policy, you're wasting your time and your... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, precisely to frame the profound significance and worrying practical consequences for relations between Israel and Palestine of what is happening in the Gaza Strip in these weeks, I would like to start from the following and tragic data: since March 30, the Israeli army killed 25 Palestinians who had taken part in the protests, including there are also 3 children and a journalist. There are more than 2 000 wounded, including 350 minors and 76 are women. The Israeli army, as reported by numerous agencies, is now also firing on journalists and I remember that firing on unarmed civilians is a war crime, just as it is of absolute gravity the naval blockade and land of the Gaza strip by Israel, which has turned this strip of land into a humanitarian bomb on which, except in cases of violent deaths, often decreases silence by the entire west . We have said this and we repeat it: the High Representative's appeals to the solution of the two states cannot suffice if nothing is done. So we must, as in the West Bank, for example, review the EU-Israel Association Agreement if it perseveres in its expansionist and discriminatory policies towards the entire people Palestinian.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, with my speech, I want to support this consensus, which is presented here on a topic as sensitive as the situation in the Gaza Strip. The resolution deals with specific cases of individuals detained by Hamas in the Gaza Strip and calls for their release. Murders of civilians are unacceptable to us, whichever one of both sides is committed. We call for a de-escalation of violence on both sides, because the Gaza Strip is becoming an uninhabitable zone, contributing to the radicalisation of its people. The most important message of this resolution, which differs from all previous ones, is the recognition that Israel faces major challenges in security and that it must protect its territory and borders beyond the use of reasonable means. The resolution condemns the terrorist attacks on Israel carried out from the Gaza Strip by Hamas and other militant groups, including firing rockets, so I will support this resolution.

name: Ana GOMES
text: — Mr President, Gaza is the largest open-air prison on the planet, a disgrace to humanity. Gaza suffers from the triple oppression of Hamas, the cruel Israeli blockade and the illegal occupation of Palestine by Israel. Without a viable State of Palestine there will be no peace and no peace in Israel, which has legitimacy and existence at stake. There are already 30 dead and 2 000 wounded, many women and children, at the armed and criminally disproportionate hands of the Israeli defence forces in the last protests of the desperate people in Gaza. In this resolution, Parliament calls for what the United Nations is asking for, the minimum: an end to the blockade, the release of political prisoners, international and independent investigation into crimes against the unarmed and desperate Protestants in Gaza. What does the EU have not to reflect in its relationship with Israel the violations that undermine the association agreement? Why do you let yourself be blackmailed and intimidated by Israel? Why do you close your eyes to the heinous crimes and consequences of Israel's illegal occupation of Palestine against regional, European and global security?

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after the speeches of my colleagues, I can only appeal to Commissioner Malmström, who represents the Commission here: the lives of Palestinians are worth no less of the lives of others. You can't talk about Israel's security when 30 unarmed protesters are killed, when Israeli snipers scream “Wow!” to the fact that you hit a human life. We cannot subordinate respect for human rights to political alliances which should be questioned, as the association agreement between the European Union and Israel should be questioned, since Israel doesn't respect UN resolutions and doesn't respect basic human rights. Finally, I appeal to the Italian government to prevent the departure of the Giro d'Italia from Israel: it is yet another provocation, it is something that once again goes to offend the dignity of the Palestinian people. The Giro d'Italia does not have to start from Israel.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the 11th year of blockade in the Gaza Strip and living conditions are reaching unsustainable levels. 47% of households suffer from food insecurity; 97% of running water is non-drinkable; 40% of the population is unemployed. The strip, according to the United Nations, could become unlivable by 2020. Can we be surprised if thousands of Palestinians started a mass protest on the borders with Israel? Instead, we must be indignant at the blood spilled: 30 dead, more than 2 000 wounded, all Palestinians, with the Israeli authorities firing directly on the crowd on several occasions. We want an independent and transparent investigation, but we demand even more respect for the fourth Geneva Convention, which is clearly trampled. In future new generations, when they study history, will wonder how it was possible that nearly two million people, for more than ten years, lived in the worst open-air prison in the world and judge us: they will judge us for our silence and judge us for not suspending this agreement. This block has to stop!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I congratulate those who worked so hard to bring this resolution here before us today. We have to condemn all violence, no matter who the perpetrators are. But at the same time we have to look at things from a point of view of the long-term perspective. One MEP said that we have to be clear on which side we are on. Isn’t that exactly the problem when you’re trying to bring peace – taking sides? I know from Northern Ireland that, if the European Union (which played a very important part), and especially the US special envoy, George Mitchell, wasn’t seen to be neutral and impartial by both sides, we wouldn’t have the Good Friday Agreement: now, 20 years of peace. Similar diplomacy is needed if we are to bring about the two-state solution, which we all desire, I think, in Israel and the Gaza Strip, and I think we have a very important role to play in that. But we must get the confidence of both sides: get them around a table and hash out an agreement, for ever more. This cannot continue: killings after killings after killings.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Mr President, as several speakers have said, the humanitarian situation in Gaza is particularly worrying and dramatic. We are talking about the largest open-air prison in the world. Israel claims to defend itself but, in fact, it attacks and respects neither human rights nor human life. We have a duty here to denounce this violence and to investigate independently what is happening in this part of the world. We must demand an end to the blockade of Gaza and allow humanitarian organizations to intervene. In essence, it is the two-State political solution that we call for which we hope will finally put an end to this near-centuries-old conflict. The European Union must do its utmost to that end, even if necessary, to revert to the agreements with Israel.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I’d like to state my solidarity with people living in Gaza, especially women and children, who’ve been living in horrendous conditions for far too long. Those of us who care about human dignity are appalled to see how Israel continues to turn a blind eye to the humanitarian consequences of its colonial policy. Israel uses security as an excuse far too often, as we well know when we speak to veterans from Breaking the Silence. These are veterans of the Israel Defence Forces. I’d also like to take this opportunity to state my solidarity with colleagues, who like me, have been accused of being anti-Semitic simply because we are critical of Israel’s policy in Palestine. I was shocked, therefore, to learn that my colleague Ana Gomes was the target of a smear campaign, including comments from EU officials, who should have been neutral. This is unacceptable, and I support her call for an investigation into this incident.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, recent events in Gaza are a stark reminder of how volatile the situation is without a clear political horizon. And that is why the European Union is consistently keeping the Middle East situation and the peace process high on the political agenda, at a time, moreover, when the region faces many other challenges. The High Representative/Vice President was at the summit of the League of Arab States this past Sunday, where she met several leaders including President Abbas and the King of Jordan. On the recent protests in Gaza. The European Union has been crystal clear: freedom of expression and freedom of assembly are fundamental rights that must be respected by all and Israel must respect the right to peaceful protests and proportionality in the use of force when defending its legitimate security interests. The immediate priority for all sides must now be to prevent any further escalation and loss of life. We call for utmost restraint and responsibility. Those leading the protest in Gaza must ensure that they remain strictly non-violent and are not exploited for other means. The human rights situation in Gaza that you referred to cannot be separated from the broader political context, which contributes to a worsening situation on the ground. That is why the EU, together with our partners, has put a strong focus on Gaza in the last month, with two ad hoc liaison committee meetings in Brussels and a successful donor conference on the Gaza desalination plant, with a project on energy and more humanitarian aid. We are also ready if the political conditions are met to assist in the re-opening of the Rafah crossing, which would be a game-changer for freedom of movement in Gaza. However, all these efforts … (President: Excuse me Madam Commissioner. Dear colleagues please, you don’t have to love the Commission but you should respect when the Commissioner is talking. Be quiet. Please, Madam Commissioner.) (Applause) Thank you. Israel needs to allow more access and movement. The Palestinian leadership or the Palestinian factions must assume their responsibilities for the people in Gaza. We are also engaging with Egypt in support of their efforts to bring back the Palestinian Authority to Gaza, but the latest developments show how fragile this process is. The legitimate rights of Palestinians to self-determination in their own state and the legitimate rights of the Israelis to live in peace, security and recognised borders will only be achieved through a negotiated two-state solution. I know this is an objective we all share, and we are looking forward to working with you towards that goal. From this debate I conclude that it is our common goal to ensure a sustainable solution is found for the situation in Gaza, with a return to the Palestinian Authority to resume its full responsibilities on the Strip, and sustained opening of the crossing points. The European Union will continue to support the process in its most effective way with all the instruments that we have. So thank you for this debate, for the work you do highlighting the situation, this is certainly not the last time we will be discussing this issue.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place after the debates end, at 12 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Sander LOONES
text: in writing. — (NL) This resolution concerns the recent uprisings in Gaza. First of all, N-VA deplores the innocent victims and calls on all parties to calm down. N-VA defends freedom of expression but condemns any form of violence. In addition, our party calls on the Israeli authorities to respect the principle of proportionality in its actions. We want the political dialogue to be restarted as soon as possible and a two-state solution to be worked out.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. – We need a resolution which is as balanced as possible. Therefore, I am deeply convinced that a third-party investigation is not acceptable. Israel has an excellent record of investigating its own military actions and drawing the necessary conclusions to redress any exceptions to the proper implementation of its legitimate right to self-defence. Israel itself is also a vibrant democracy and the army’s activity is a constant source of healthy public and political debate which itself contributes to the necessary oversight. To call for an independent investigation, even before the IDF has completed its own inquiry, is therefore at the very least premature and implies a grave accusation against a friendly country: namely, that its democratic process cannot possibly be trusted. The notion of a possible ICC inquiry is particularly unjustified. Given the legal principle of complementarity under the Rome Statute, the ICC can only initiate cases when a state to whom an alleged perpetrator belonged was unwilling or unable to act. In the case of Israel, that criteria has not been met because Israel has a proven track record of investigating its own military and is, as mentioned, in the process of investigating the recent events.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to apologise, to our colleagues: I am neither the initiator of this vote today, nor a fan of interventions in voting time. However, this voice against believes a short clarification is in order. This is a report on repealing 10 legal acts in the area of business statistics and replacing them with one.
