One instead of ten spirit goes against the spirit of the vote in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, which was 57 against 6. Why is it now on the agenda? Because some of my colleagues’ shadows introduced an additional amendment on additional taxation information, which was rejected. Of course taxation is important. However, we already have automatic exchange on taxation between tax authorities and a separate initiative in Parliament on country—by—country reporting on taxation. But it has been blocked in the Council since July 2017, as my colleagues from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs know. There is a good reason not to place it in a very technical dossier on business statistics. There is no demand for that data in the business community, and I am sure that when we place it in this technical dossier, it stays as it is now with ten regulations instead of one. Therefore, I defend the mandate and hope you manage to leave on time.

name: Dan NICA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, the opposition that we have expressed was due to a very simple fact: we do not believe in discrimination and we do not believe that large corporations need to receive treatment that is more favourable to them than that we apply to businesses small, some medium-sized enterprises. If all businesses in the European Union are obliged to communicate their taxes for statistical purposes, why make an exception for large corporations? What would be the motivation? It is missing, and that is why our vote is no, and I call on all colleagues to vote no.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: We now move to the next item, the report by Mr Buzek. This is a decision by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy to enter into negotiations on the basis of the report by Mr Buzek concerning common rules for the internal market in natural gas. A plenary vote on the committee’s decision was originally requested by the GUE/NGL and ENF Groups. Together, they constitute the so-called medium threshold, but the GUE/NGL Group has now withdrawn its request, and if there are no other requests for this vote to take place, the vote will be withdrawn from the agenda and the committee may enter into negotiations with immediate effect. Are there any other requests? No. So this means that I don’t need to put this to a vote and it will be withdrawn from the agenda.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I supported the directive proposing measures against the use of financial systems for money laundering or terrorist financing. I believe that this directive does exactly what citizens expect from the Union. Terrorism financing is closely linked to crime and money laundering. Moreover, these phenomena do not know boundaries and, on the contrary, take advantage of the fact that states do not adequately inform each other, cooperate, or have different rules. Therefore, it is logical that there is legislation at the Union level. In particular, I consider it very important those measures which cancel the anonymity of ownership and monetary transactions above a certain limit, which at the same time must be sufficiently low. I believe this directive will help improve the situation against money laundering and terrorism.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this very important legislative proposal. This legal instrument will help us to prevent the cases where the Union’s financial system has been abused for money laundering, fraud, terrorist financing or other illicit activities by third parties. We need to put an end to dirty money – whether from Isis or Russian oligarchs – residing in EU banks. With this crucial proposal, financial intelligence units will be able to have direct access to the information they need on real owners of companies and trusts, and not the names on ‘letterboxes’. It will provide us with a tool to disclose complicated schemes of illicit activity and will bring more transparency to the system.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, I supported this report because I firmly believe that the financial system has an urgent need to prevent the financing of terrorist organisations through it. We can address the latest striking cases with the birth and construction of the Islamic State terrorist organization, which uses a number of financial organizations and institutions to fund its extremely dangerous and illegal activities. Financial systems must be safeguarded from the penetration of dirty money into them and money laundering to finance terrorist threats that pose the greatest danger to the lives and health of citizens of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I consider the fight against money laundering extremely important and it is good that the European Union is fighting this phenomenon, this international crime. On the other hand, I must say that this directive contains certain provisions that cause, for example, embarrassment for certain professional groups in my country, in the Czech Republic. I have received many protests, for example, from Czech antiquarians who perceive that the general, area regulation will mainly affect small and medium-sized decent entrepreneurs who, for example, trade antiques and cultural artifacts. I finally refrained because I feel that some of the wording in the submitted text may have been more accurate, could have been more unequivocal, and I will only hope that the concerns raised by the Czech Republic the public, will not eventually come true and that the directive will really affect money laundering and will not bully and affect small and medium-sized entrepreneurs with cultural artifacts in Czech to the republic.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, money laundering is a global challenge and it’s being met largely with global solutions, sometimes slightly more high profile, as is the case with the G20’s initiatives, often in an unglamorous, unremarked, and unreported way among national regulators. The question is, why does the European Union need additional jurisdiction in this field? Money laundering isn’t particularly a problem that afflicts people trying to shift money from one Member State to another. Of course there is a role for the European Union to support global initiatives, but I suspect that there are also people who see this as a general opportunity to extend EU jurisdiction.  There is, after all, some precedent here. When the FBI was set up in the United States its original purpose was to tackle terrorism and human trafficking and money laundering. All of the same things that were set up as targets for Europol and for Eurojust. It is, of course, a good thing to exchange information and to cooperate, but we should be very careful before creating a new bureaucracy with power to intervene directly within the national jurisdictions.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tacaím go hiomlán leis an tuairisc seo. Is mór an trua go bhfuil an sceimhlitheoireacht tar éis teacht chun cinn san Eoraip le blianta beaga anuas, anseo sa Fhrainc ach go háirithe. Tá súil agam go gcabhróidh an scéim seo chun stop a chur leis an treocht imníoch seo. Caithfear rialacha láidre a chur i bhfeidhm ó thaobh trédhearcacht i gcórais airgeadais ionas nach féidir le grúpaí coiriúla méid mór airgead a chur i dtaisce i ngan fhios do na heagraíochtaí stáit. Cabhróidh comhoibriú idir na Ballstáit go mór leis seo chomh maith. Gan dabht, is é meas ar chearta daonna bunchloch an Aontais Eorpaigh. Táim sásta go bhfuil cothromaíocht sroichte ag an tuairisc seo idir chearta príobháideachais agus saoirse eacnamaíochta a chaomhnú agus slándáil a fheabhsú. Go raibh maith agat as ucht an seans a thabhairt dom é seo a dhéanamh.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, the Dieselgate scandal shows that consumers and the environment are the main victims of a car type-approval regime that cannot be relied upon and that has been subject to systematic abuse. So I welcome the fact that European Union law will be updated to make type-approval rules stronger and more effective. The new rules will require Member States regularly to check cars circulating on their roads for compliance with relevant environmental and safety standards. And the European Commission will carry out audits of national car type-approval authorities and have the possibility to initiate EU-wide recalls. It will also be able to challenge the validity of inspection systems and issue fines of up to EUR 30 000 per non-compliant car. I wanted the new rules to be effective sooner given the evidence of abuse uncovered. However, I am nevertheless pleased that they will take effect before the end of 2020, and so during the transition period currently proposed following the planned exit of the UK from the EU. But it is very disappointing that the initial proposals to break the financial link between car makers and test laboratories were dropped and that the idea of a powerful new agency providing tough oversight of the car industry across Europe was also rejected.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulation we have voted on organic production and labelling of organic products makes important efforts and gives guarantees, for example, on improving food quality, environmental protection and animal welfare, this throughout the production chain. It also enunciates important basic principles: the prohibition of the use of chemical pesticides and synthetic fertilizers as well as the limitation on the use of antibiotics. But what will in fact be the results? They will be scarce, in our opinion, because pesticide residue thresholds will be lower than those used now, to date, in many Member States, for example Italy. By doing so, then, we have lowered existing standards, effectively penalizing the most conscientious farmers. Consumers should be properly informed and their judgment empowered, not bypassed through finely biological labelling. That is why our vote was negative.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, the report adopted today on the future of organic production is an important step in the development of the sector. Scientific studies have shown that organic products have a positive effect on sensitive members of our society, such as children, adolescents, but also pregnant women and people with serious illnesses. The interest and demand for quality products continues to grow both in the European Union and in my country — Bulgaria. With this, however, the expectations of quality guarantees grow. In this regard, I believe that it is extremely important that the control is strictly and consistently followed, given the rogue practices of farmers who spray near apiaries without warning them, or spray preparations with rapid decay. I am of the opinion that checks must remain and be an important and indissoluble part of organic production. I support the report on the introduction of stricter import rules. Organic production is related to the growing process. For this reason, I believe that it is entirely fair that the same conditions should be available for producers in third countries outside the European Union.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, in recent years the scope of organic farming and demand for organic products have grown dramatically. EU citizens see it as a source of a healthy lifestyle and sustainability. It is estimated that the total value of the eco-market in the European Union amounts to up to EUR 31 billion. Taking this into account, I support this proposal aiming at the harmonisation of production rules and reducing the risk of contamination from pesticides in organic farms. This means that farmers will still have the choice of cultivating both conventional and eco-production, but will have to comply with certain standards respectively. We need to ensure the credibility of the organic logo and help consumers make informed choices, as well as to provide incentives for eco-farming in our states.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuairisce seo toisc gur dul chun cinn an-tábhachtach é.  Ar fud an Aontais, níl go leor feirmeoireachta orgánaí chun an t-éileamh atá ar bhia orgánach a líonadh. Faoi láthair, táimid ag cailleadh amach ar an margadh seo. Ach tá seans againn anois an bia orgánach a tháirgeadh san Aontas in ionad leanúint ar aghaidh á iompórtáil.  Tá go leor feirmeoirí Éireannacha a úsáideann modhanna talmhaíochta nach bhfuil i bhfad ón bhfeirmeoireacht orgánach ach braitheann siad go bhfuil an iomarca próisis agus páipéarachais ag baint le stádas orgánach a athnuachan. Cabhróidh an tuairisc seo chun an bac seo a shárú. Tá caighdeán ard ag baint le bia orgánach faoi láthair. Cinntíonn an tuairisc seo nach dtiocfaidh athrú air seo agus an talmhaíocht orgánach á leathnú. Molaim ar fheirmeoirí trasna na hEorpa, agus go háirithe in Éirinn, an deis seo a thapú.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, it is important that today the European Parliament has adopted a call to protect investigative journalists in Europe. The media is a pillar of democracy, that's why we need investigative, courageous journalists. I appreciate the protests in Slovakia, which creates pressure to investigate the murder of Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend. We cannot tolerate the fact that, after a long time in Malta, progress in the investigation of the murder of Maltese journalist Caruanova Galizio, who also figured in the investigation, is still not in the investigative activities against political corruption. This is why it is important that the European Parliament is taking this role and calls on Member States to take measures against the intimidation of journalists, including condemning public insults to politicians journalists. A journalist in a free society cannot live in fear.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Madam President, the octopus of money laundering kills journalists, but cannot kill the truth, cannot kill words written in articles, blogs, Facebook or books. Ján Kuciak was assassinated, we all know. His colleagues are working to find out the truth about who killed him and who gave the order to kill him. It is important to say how the politicians in Slovakia reacted: the Minister of Interior, the Chief of Police and, on 15 March 2018, the Prime Minister of Slovakia Robert Fico resigned. Prime Minister Muscat should also follow the example of the Slovak Prime Minister, because there is also an assassination of investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, but it is a matter of honor and responsibility in each individual case. Now the resolution calls on the authorities to investigate who gave the order to kill them. It seems to me hypocrisy: only investigative journalists, only their colleagues will find out the truth, not the authorities, who are practically involved in these killings.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I strongly support the resolution, in particular its call for the highest level of protection for investigative journalists and whistle-blowers.  As a journalist and a Member of the European Parliament, and also as a citizen of Latvia, a state where serious investigative journalism is lacking, I am sure that we must, and can, do more for our journalists.  Speaking about disinformation and fake news in this House, we have repeatedly stated the need to stimulate critical thinking and media literacy among our citizens. They have the right to be more demanding and to call for investigations. Ján Kuciak did crucial work on large-scale tax evasion scandals, tax fraud, corruption and money-laundering, and it is regrettable that the simple duty of a journalist requires extraordinary courage, even in the EU.  It is the corrupted politicians that should be afraid of journalists, not vice versa. If our journalists operate in a climate of intimidation and fear we shall have weak and toothless journalism and, as a result, a weak civil society.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — L-ewwelnett nirringrazzja lill-kollegi f'dan il-parlament li regrreferew gall-każ ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia. Irrid ngЂid li llum gЂandek 25 urnalist minn madwar id-dinja li qegdin ikomplu jinvestigaw l-istejjer li hija kienet qiegЂda tadem fuqhom. Huwa b'hekk biss li x-xogЂol investigattiv ta' urnalisti bshort al Daphne Caruana Galizia u Ján Kuciak inkomplu narsuh, galiex meta urnalisti bЂal dawn jitwaqqfu mix-xogЂol tageinhom, dak li jkun grajoed jito ri huwa attakk kontra s-sowherejetà kollha biex ma nirivux il-verità li gandna dritt gatmosaliha. Irrid ngShoid li f'Malta, Il-gvern, flok ma jipprova jsib min huwa verament responsabbli gall-qtil ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia, ikompli b'attività bal li jiwickenustifika S-slapp li hija proprio użata kontra urnalisti li jagmlu l-idma taghom. F'irkostanzi bЂal dawn huwa d-dmir tagЂna f'dan Il-parlament Ewropew li nkomplu niddefendu l-- urnaliżmu investigattiv galiex huwa mibni fuq il-libertà tal-espressjon. Il-mono sieb li nagthe laq bih huwa, huwa b'hekk biss li ma nshort allux lil min irid jidfen lil dawn il-enurnalisti jidfen ukoll il-verità li huma kienu qegthe din jistthe arrat.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — The murder of journalist Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend caused great dismay not only in Slovakia but also throughout Europe. Today we adopted a resolution designed to help protect investigative journalists in Europe. Although I very much wanted to vote in favour of such a resolution because I think journalists must have protection for their work, I did not support the resolution in the end. In fact, points have come into the resolution which, in my opinion, are distorting and confusing. They relate to freedom of the media in Slovakia. In Reporters Without Borders, Slovakia ranks 17th in the world ranking of press freedom from 180 ranked countries. Another contentious point is one where there is talk about politicizing the choice of prosecutors. The Prosecutor General in Slovakia is approved by secret ballot in the National Council of the Slovak Republic. Finally, the contentious point is also one that speaks of local media being subjected to political pressures. I don't know about such pressures. For this reason, we have asked for these points to be included in a separate vote. But since they were finally approved, I could not support the resolution. But I am in favour of protecting journalists and expect effective European legislation from the Commission to protect journalists.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: — Madam President, colleagues. I welcomed the European Parliament resolution dealing with the murder of journalist Jan Kuciak and his fiancee. I signed up for the text prepared by my colleague Sulík's office. This text calls on the Slovak authorities to investigate the murder in a thorough manner, which has not yet come to, to more rigorous control of the use of Eurofunds, especially in our agro-sector. It expresses doubts about the politicisation of the attorney general's office. Slovakia is a proud and sovereign country. Unfortunately, we have people at the forefront of it who support fraud of enormous proportions. Not to mention the cases of verbal and physical violence that happens in our country. This has to come to an end and we cannot allow it to continue. I firmly believe that Slovakia will wake up after this step and choose god-fearing representatives. Demonstrations on Slovak streets showed that even 29 years after the tender revolution, the Slovak public is not completely apathetic. I am particularly pleased with the initiative of young people who have not resigned and actively participated in the country. Thank you to all who have endured and have not given up in the fight against corruption and abuse of power by our politicians. It's not right.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: –Madam President, when we talk about shrinking space for civil society in this Parliament we usually talk about countries outside of the European Union, but we do have a shrinking space even inside the Union. For example in Hungary the law is about to be voted that requires every organisation that ‘supports immigration’ to obtain national security clearance. In Poland restrictions have already been passed on the right to the civil society organisations to demonstrate during the December UN climate change talks in Qatar. So yes, we do need the instrument even here in the EU and I do support it strongly.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, recent breaches of the rule of law in fellow EU Member States have shown once again that respect for European values needs to be significantly stepped up and can no longer be taken for granted. This tendency will remain in future as well. Therefore I fully support the establishment of the European values instrument within the next MFF. We are seeing the positive results of similar instruments in the EU neighbourhoods, and I believe that the time has come to apply some similar instruments within the EU Member States as well. Funding civil society organisations in the Member States will help us strengthen civil society, promote democracy, government accountability and respect for human rights. There is nothing more important than defending these values, because these are the values on which the European Union is based.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, I voted against this report because, in my opinion, one big mistake is being made here. There is no doubt, civil society and its organisations are important and must have their support. However, in the form of civil organisations, civil society in many countries, especially in the eastern part of the European Union, attempts are being made at unacceptable influences and suggestions, and the traditional values of these countries change. Each country has its history, has its traditions, has its own biography. It is the right of every country and every society in the European Union to defend its traditions and its values. On the one hand, we argue that the European Union is based on equal in difference, and on the other hand we are trying to change the values of some of the countries in the European Union. This is unacceptable and unacceptable. For this reason, we believe in our group that traditional values must be protected and states and societies should be able to maintain their self-awareness and their identity.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the success of the European project has made us think that the values in our Treaties are both exceptional and universal. However, with time we have to realise that not only our normative transformation power is limited, but that even at home our democracy is suffering. We do not have the responsibility to democratise each and every partner, and there is no such thing as ‘democrat international’, but it is true that we need to have a functional democracy within the EU. Therefore I suggest that the European values instrument should not only finance NGOs, it should also provide monitoring and scrutiny on the ground. Be sure that we will discover many uncomfortable truths about us. One such truth is the deprivation of the political and civil rights of the so-called ‘non-citizens’ of Latvia and Estonia, who are also restricted in their social and economic rights. Attention, colleagues: in the case of Latvia we are speaking of almost 20% of the population. Such discrimination creates a divided society and the consequences bring security risks. If we wish to call EU countries ‘strong democracies’, we have at least to end a phenomenon of forced statelessness within our borders.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Madam President, I did not vote in favour of this resolution and I look at it, I must say, with great suspicion. It sounds very noble, of course, if we say something about a European instrument to support NGOs that will promote democracy, rule of law and fundamental values, but I know how things go here, and I am very afraid that this fund will become a propaganda tool for the only right and allowed idea of the EU and European integration, so that it will hide under it supporting the deepening of European integration, the strengthening of European institutions, and that it really does not lend itself to taxpayers' money, public funds. I hope that the European Parliament will properly control how these funds are used, how they are provided, and that this will be broken down according to objective criteria, not by criteria partisanship, not by criteria, who is friends with whom and who proclaims the only correct opinions. I am very worried about this because we have witnessed it several times in the past and therefore I could not vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I want to comment on this report because national parliaments form the very core of the EU's democratic legitimacy and I see strengthening their role as the best means, how to continue to overcome the so-called democratic deficit. I see it as pivotal that the Commission listens to national parliaments who are clamoring for subsidiarity in their resolutions. I appreciate the proposal for a 'European week', which would consist of a one-week reservation for European affairs, which would allow both MPs and senators to debate with the leaders of EU institutions. I think it would help a better understanding of processes as well as current European topics. That would add to greater transparency. On the contrary, I am sceptical of the new instrument, the so-called minority opinion, because national parliaments would rather appreciate a better quality response to their reports. Unfortunately, the Commission responds mostly rather formally, or rather more quality than quantity.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the issue of vaccines, also complicates the tools that the media world has made available, in particular social media, have created a condition of total disinformation, which then resulted in a dimension of aversion to vaccines, which instead represent an indispensable scientific tool in order to prevent and eradicate the many diseases that our world over the years he managed to defeat. I also think that the need to make students, parents and the world that gravitates around communication thoroughly understand, is fundamental because the coverage that the World Health Organisation took us recommends in order to be quiet and safe is equal to 95% of the population. Going below this threshold would mean endangering the health of our children and, above all, not securing the level of scientific coverage we have achieved so far.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Madam President! Unfortunately, although I appreciate the value and role of vaccination as a doctor, I voted against the report on vaccination evasion in Europe, which has contributed to a number of factors, including not only fear of sometimes severe post-vaccination complications, but also continuing to increase The number of mandatory vaccinations administered even to children in the first day of life, which provokes all kinds of anti-vaccine movements. Amendments submitted by me regarding the control of vaccines, the organisation of a compensation fund for severe post-vaccination complications, especially the voluntary vaccination occurring in Germany, Scandinavia and twenty other countries, of course, outside the situation of danger Epidemiological — as well as the obligation to provide information to parents about possible side actions and the establishment of a register of post-vaccination activities, have not been adopted, and after all, these changes in the resolution would lead to greater transparency and prevention of rampant fears and misinformation regarding the preventive role of vaccination.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: - Madam President! As a co-author of this resolution, I voted in favour of it, of course. Vaccines have basically become such a victim of their own success, because it is through vaccines that the largest infectious plagues of our public health in Europe and the world have been eliminated. Unfortunately, the fact that they have become a victim of their success, part of people have simply given up on them, because they believe that such medical conditions, such dangers do not exist, and this is not true as even if the return of measles among children, among the people of Europe. And the second thing, of course, is fear, this fear is constantly stoked by all sorts of associations and anti-vaccine actions. I think it's good that such a resolution has been passed. I believe that the issue of course is essentially the responsibility of the Member States because that is the health care system, but the European Union should be involved in promoting best practice, increasing transparency and reducing vaccine prices.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: — Madam President, I voted with both hands on this resolution on what we kindly call 'reluctance to immunization'. I will be a little more straightforward. Anti-vaccine speeches are absolutely irresponsible! A parent who makes this choice not only endangers the health of his child, but also the health of the rest of society, since the child can then transmit and convey the virus. More than 30,000 infections, sometimes fatal, could be prevented each year in Europe if vaccinations were carried out correctly. Thirty thousand is considerable! In some parts of Europe today, measles outbreaks, for example, are reoccurring and children succumbing to them. In 2018, it is perfectly unbearable. Obviously, everything goes there: conspiracy theories, collusions, lobbying, pharmaceutical industry. Now, the facts are here: Europe today is the most skeptical region of the world about vaccines, where the Enlightenment, Pastor and modern medicine have emerged. The world is walking on its head, Madam President.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that growing public fluctuations about vaccines and the reduction in vaccination rates in Europe are a worrying phenomenon. I believe that a broad public debate is needed at both European and national level. Citizens' mistrust is also having its consequences — outbreaks of measles outbreak in a number of Member States whose prevention has been possible. The mass hysteria associated with the side effects of vaccination leads even the bravest parent to vaccinate their child with a curled heart. What we do know for certain, however, is that vaccination is of the utmost importance to collective health. We cannot afford to lose lives for lack of awareness. Over the past few years, the European Union has taken on a major refugee wave, and we also need to think in the direction of prevention. Because let's be honest — a large proportion of refugees have a vague health status, and this poses an additional risk to public health.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: — (the beginning of the out-of-microphone)... gave me a serious dilemma, because on the one hand, its essence is essentially right — the introduction of a European protection order, while it's all sunk in such a feminist swamp that it's hard to sign under. Because of this dilemma, I asked my constituents their opinion and they asked me to vote uncompromising against — not because we have anything against the protection order, just because of the accompanying allowances — we buy sexist propaganda in every second paragraph, we buy into this way compulsory propaganda in schools and some additional Commissioner for Women's Affairs. My constituents don't want such a thing. I call for you to stop pushing this already really reverberated topic into every possible resolution — and this is about trade, about the Philippines, about the climate, about the media. You are boring and monothematic about this and it is simply impossible to listen to it anymore. You're obsessed with this, and I'm calling for it to stop destroying good projects with stupid insets.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I support the call to reinforce the social dimension in the European Higher Education Area. Education should not be a luxury, but it has to be inclusive to the maximum degree. Inclusiveness and equal access are the keys to guaranteeing social justice in the European Union. The Bologna Process has brought significant mobility and offered many chances to students and researchers, making European universities the best performers in many sectors, but it still has its limits.  In its current form the Bologna Process does not really create a platform for social debate on education across Europe. The fact that the EU nation-states adopt their language policies in education without any scrutiny from the EU can lead to highly undemocratic practices. To give you an example, my home country, Latvia, has recently become a victim of disproportionate education reform, doing away, de facto, with education in minority languages. What I expect from the Bologna Process is major engagement with stakeholders and a closer look at the problems on the ground.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — Polls have closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the broad written question to the Commission by Ivan Jakovčić, on behalf of the ALDE Group: State of the European Shipbuilding Industry (O-000022/2018 — B8-0019/2018) (2018/2672 (RSP).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Author. — Dear Chairman, industrial sectors of maritime equipment and shipbuilding have been among Europe's most important strategic industries for decades, employing around 450,000 people in EU Member States. These are important sectors both from economic and social standpoint as they provide quality employment for large enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises and contribute to regional industrial infrastructure. In Europe today there are about 150 large shipyards, many of which are active on the world market with a market share of around 6% when it comes to tonnage. However, respected commissioner, shipbuilding nations in Europe are too weak to cope with the pressure of competition from Asia, especially, of course, from China and South Korea where there are special national strategies for their shipbuilding with clear support goals. Given the Leadership 2020 initiative, does the European Commission have a specific plan to create a comprehensive industrial strategy for the European maritime sector and the shipbuilding sector to support long-term competitiveness, economic stability and growth of this important sector? Is the Commission taking concrete measures to preserve and support the high-tech and high value competitive advantage of European shipbuilding? Does the Commission have clear policies and measures in place today to deal with the threats posed by unfair international competition and the absence of global trade rules? Those are my questions. But of course, I want to thank you here first and foremost for accepting this initiative of mine to discuss these topics and I regret that there are no other colleagues and colleagues from my country because this is especially important for Croatia. And that's why I want to partly look back on Croatian shipbuilding. I know well how important it is to ensure the survival of shipbuilding in Croatia because we are not just talking about preserving jobs, but we are talking about preserving the knowledge and skills of building a ship. Uljanik from Pula, of course, I know best, can become a true European Silicon Valley of shipbuilding smarts and science. The assumption for this is a quick and serious and long-term reaction of state and European institutions. Along with Uljanik, and May 3rd from Rijeka, Brodosplit and HBT from Dalmatia are still companies that have knowledge and market, but need European and national assistance. Namely, the main problem is primarily of a financial nature. And this financing of ship construction and financing of the customer of that ship, as others do, and that is crucial for the survival of shipbuilding, not only in Croatia. That is why I call on the European Commission to design and propose the establishment of a special instrument so that the European building industry can be financed in a competitive way. Often here, Madam Commissioner, we talk about the need to reindustrialize Europe. Instead of first adopting effective measures to save those industries that have synergistic, technological, scientific and economic strength, which can carry the development of Europe in the future. I therefore propose to immediately stop the closure or liquidation of shipyards in the Member States of the European Union. Of course this also means a new definition of measures and criteria, which must be done together by the European Commission and the governments of the Member States concerned. We cannot remain silent as one of Europe's key industries disappears, while at the same time our partners in other parts of the world are pursuing their policy of open subsidies and helping their shipbuilding industry. I understand the need for market and open access because, after all, I am in a family of liberals, but if competition is non-market and illiberal and it does everything to save its industry, then I call for us to do so too. For me, it is completely unacceptable to close my eyes in the face of the constant loss of the share of European producers in the world market. Shipbuilding is a symbol of the connection of European industry because our ship, a European ship, is a common European product in which they are many materials and products that are assembled in a ship in one country and come from a number of other countries. So, let's create a new concept and strategy for shipbuilding conservation immediately.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly, I want to thank the House for having this opportunity to discuss this important sector of European industry. This is important for most of the European Member States. Let me start my remarks by looking at the wider context. As you maybe remember, in September last year, President Juncker gave a very strong political signal about the need to make our industries stronger, and to make our industries more competitive. Just a few weeks after this, we at the Commission presented and adopted and comprehensive industrial policy strategy. The strategy addresses the remaining gaps with actions that this Commission and this Parliament can still carry out. Even though time is rather short, I think we can still take action here. So, the document: our horizontal industrial strategies are empowering all sectors to innovate and to adapt. The ship building sector is one of many sectors within this framework, and some actions can be the same for all of them, although each sector has its own specifics. Within this framework, we have also taken concrete action to support industrial transformation in specific sectors. And this is an exact example of what we are doing. The shipbuilding and maritime equipment industries are important from both an economic and social perspective as you rightly put it, Honourable Member. They have provided highly qualified jobs contributing to regional economic development, but the global market situation, as we all know, remains difficult for a number of companies in Europe. Against this background, Leadership 2020, as adopted by all relevant stakeholders, constitutes an important initiative focusing on innovation, access to finance skills, market access and some incentives and, maybe, some support for shipyards and the maritime equipment industry. All of those topics and issues are Commission priorities. As regards the first question, on the Commission plan to support long-term competitiveness and growth, our Leadership 2020 programme provides an action plan. Most of the actions are to be decided and implemented by stakeholders themselves, but we are not resting on our laurels and are doing our job. Some actions, especially regulatory ones or negotiations with third countries’ international organisations are for the Commission to initiate or to follow. The second question, on how to preserve and support the high-tech and high-value competitive advantages of European shipbuilding. The very purpose of Leadership 2020 exercise was to identify new opportunities in the areas of innovation, the application of new technologies for the purposes of greening and diversification into new markets. Let me remind you that the recent historic decision by the global shipping industry to cut for the first time its greenhouse gas emissions is both a challenge but also an opportunity. It shows that Leadership 2020, with its strong innovation and greening focus, remains fully valid. More particularly, under the research pillar of Leadership 2020 we have actions to exploit new market opportunities and support zero-emission and energy-efficient vessels. The high-value competitive advantage of European shipbuilding cannot be preserved unless we maintain our human capital and the necessary know-how and related skills. So, in 2015, the Commission endorsed the proposal by the maritime industry to set up a maritime European Sectoral Skills Council as part of the EU-funded project entitled ‘Creating a European Skills Council for the Maritime Technology Sector’. Another initiative which we are quite proud of is maritime technologies, one of the pilot priority sectors under the blueprint for sectoral cooperation on skills. We have chosen a few sectors – seven or eight – for the first round of financing, and the maritime sector is one of them. This was launched under the new skills agenda for Europe in June 2016. Most recently, under the Erasmus+ sector skills alliances, we supported the project on maritime technologies with nearly EUR 4 million funding. This project kicked off in 2018, just a few weeks ago. Regarding your question on the need for a clear policy on the measures to target threats under the unfair international competition. Let me say that, as you also rightly say, the shipbuilding nations in Europe are too weak to cope with the competitive pressure from Asia. Again, this is exactly what our document Leadership 2020 aims to change. The Commission continues to negotiate in the framework of the OECD Working Group on shipbuilding. The sixth EU-China shipbuilding dialogue took place in March 27 last year in Beijing. The objective was to address obstacles limiting business opportunities in China, for instance restrictions on ownership, local content requirements in granting subsidies, weak protection of intellectual property rights, etc. Such exchanges do not bring immediate results, but they represent the only way forward to demonstrate the mutual benefits of fair trade relations to China and other countries. A word on foreign direct investment (FDI): Europe needs to remain open to FDI. However, let’s not be naive, this openness cannot mean allowing transactions by foreign governments or state-owned foreign investors with a hidden agenda. They may seek to gain control of European companies, firms whose activities are critical for the EU or national security and public order. The FDI screening proposal, which is now in the hands of the Parliament and the Council, aims to target this issue. It provides a framework for screening FDI transactions that may pose a risk. Critical infrastructure, like ports and shipyards, are included in the proposal. Finally, a recent study commissioned by the Commission on the new trends in globalisation in shipbuilding and maritime suppliers identifies a number of challenges but also – even more importantly – gives concrete recommendations. This Commission has been discussing those recommendations with industry representatives and we will draw appropriate conclusions. This will also be a part of our discussion at the next MFF.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it gives me great pleasure to represent the EPP here this afternoon. The EPP are fully committed to industrialisation of Europe and keeping our competitiveness. I would like to congratulate the ALDE Group and support and, indeed, reiterate their question on this crucial issue, which was so well presented to us just now by Ivan Jakovčić. The future of the European shipbuilding sector is under great threat from growing international shipbuilding industries, and only a clear, targeted EU shipbuilding policy offering an integrated and unified approach towards international competition will help Europe to cope with these competitive and societal challenges. We need to develop a collective strategy that rivals that of our Asian counterparts, for example. Ireland, my country, is an island nation and is well served by a thriving shipbuilding industry and can contribute greatly to a joint European effort to re-jig the sector. During the 1820s and 30s Cork, in my constituency, became the most important shipbuilding centre in the country and continued to be important until the 1860s. The Verolme docks at Rushbrooke in Cobh once employed over 1100 people in shipbuilding and many large ships were built and launched from there. This included a number of vessels such as the L.E. Eithne, which has been for the Irish naval service, which has its headquarters nearby. The Verolme dockyard unfortunately closed in 1984 with major job losses to the area and greatly contributed to Ireland’s dwindling shipbuilding sector. The Port of Cork, however, is the second biggest in the country and linked to major other ports. This could contribute greatly to this development. Small boat building, repair and refurbishment and offshore operation and maintenance continue to operate in Cork and throughout Ireland, but the potential beneficial opportunities in reviving this once-thriving shipbuilding industry are endless. Limerick, also in my constituency, has Foynes port, a wonderful port. I’m currently working with the port company CEO, Pat Keating, to get it upgraded to corridor status. Given that it is one of Europe’s most naturally deep ports, it has huge potential. And on May 18 I will be guest speaker at a major conference in Limerick organised by Foynes port. I want to thank the Commission, who will be taking part there are and will be able to see the port for themselves. Also, there are many small fishing ports in my constituency, such places as Kilmore Quay, Castletownbere, Dingle and Dunmore East. They are fishing ports, they are vital for the economy of the constituencies and we must give them every opportunity to develop. Finally, I just want to say, we also have Rosslare harbour in my constituency. This is used for ferries for human beings and for goods and also for haulage. Especially in a post-Brexit era its going become of major importance. So we have an opportunity to do what our President Antonio Tajani once said to stop the industrial massacre of Europe and especially to rebuild our shipping industry. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue. — Dear Head of the sitting, Dear Colleagues, thank you for accepting my blue card question! As we know, at the moment in the shipbuilding industry, China as a state and Chinese shipbuilding sector creates enormous competition for Europe. Do you see in the near future opportunities for the European shipbuilding industry to compete effectively with China's shipbuilding industry?

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card answer. – I think that not only we will but we have to be. I was encouraged by the words of the Commissioner in stating how we were going to regain our competitiveness and help our ports. I think once we put our units and our strengths together we can do an enormous amount to help the shipbuilding industry and to compete with China, and not only with China but also Korea and other places. Europe has to regain its industrial strength, as I mentioned in relation to Antonio Tajani. And that’s what we’re going to do, and we can do it together with the Commission and – as you said – the Member States.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –Mr President, today Europe is still a major player in the global shipbuilding industry. However, low demand in shipbuilding production is expected in Europe in the next 10 years. This means that this industry will face serious challenges. As far as I can see, there are few of us here in the plenary but the topic doesn’t become less important because of that. The EU is a maritime power and we need to consider all the benefits and perspectives of this sector. Our European project is unique and makes our neighbours wonder about how we ensure such a stable regulatory framework. But we need to keep in mind that the EU is not only about norms and regulations. It is about geopolitics too. The maritime industry still belongs, to a large extent, to power politics. To be a post-modern power in the world of modern nation-states requires us to be geopolitical players too. The study produced on behalf of the European Commission by BALance Technology Consulting shows that the well-being of the European shipbuilding sector has not only economic but also political, security-related and environmental implications for the European Union. This is why today Europe needs a pragmatic and visionary approach towards its shipbuilding. The wise decision has been taken in Europe in recent years to concentrate shipbuilding industry on special high-tech and high-value ships. High technology is going to give us major competitive advantages and take our shipbuilding industry out of yesterday’s world. But we should bear in mind that China also has the political objective of entering the high-tech ship market. It means that we need to think of the next steps to preserve our competitive advantage. In the absence of effective global trade rules we absolutely need a European umbrella to protect our shipbuilders who otherwise will struggle more and more every year. The shipbuilding market remains dollar-based, and that means that we have to protect this industry in Europe from financial imbalances and ensure a fair treatment for our producers. A strong shipbuilding industry also contributes to the new maritime security policies, the EU maritime security strategy, EU Arctic policies and EU naval missions. The EU Member States certainly have strong economic or strategic maritime interests. Therefore, they are reluctant to transfer more competences in this field to the Commission. But if we are to compete with the world’s major maritime powers we need to pool resources and adopt a common action. Brexit will undermine our maritime power to a certain extent, but it can also give us an impetus to go faster in building a common maritime policy. Another reason why we need an effective industrial strategy in the maritime sector is environmental concerns. The EU has an image of the most progressive power in terms of environmental regulation and it should also uphold this principle in its maritime trade relations. This will also contribute to our efforts in promoting environmental standards. Furthermore, climate change is going to uncover new maritime routes in the Arctic region. It will enable much faster transportation from Europe and Africa to Asia, rather than today when the ships pass through the Middle East and South Asia. Current routes will be abandoned as being slower, more expensive and more dangerous. This will immediately shift the competition to the north and to the Arctic region. You have to think about it already today and start to develop new technologies for the new ships able to operate in zones of the extreme North. Colleagues, I also belong to a maritime country. Speaking about the shipbuilding industry in Latvia I need to say that our major current challenges in the shipbuilding sector are the development of workers’ skills and the improvement of the marketing system. Thanks to the historical roots and old traditions of the shipbuilding sector, Latvia conserves its respected position amongst the world’s maritime power, which has been guaranteed by the introduction of some advanced materials, new manufacturing technologies and new designs. But such innovations are not enough to keep Latvian shipbuilding in good economic conditions, especially considering the slowdown of demand in Europe. Today’s shipbuilding sector is in part a knowledge-based economy, and I think that the Latvian Government has to officially state it will adopt a truly European approach to ensure the development of shipbuilding and the welfare of workers.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! I completely support the concern of the author of the interpellation and the questions to the European Commission regarding the European maritime and shipbuilding sector, even more so that the European Commission's actions have led, unfortunately, with the complicity of previous governments, to the collapse of the shipyard in Poland. Best known for the events of December 70 and the creation of Solidarity, the Gdańsk Shipyard built over a thousand ships during its operation. After regaining independence and joining the European Union, public assistance for important plants proved to be against EU rules and privatisation of the shipyard was demanded so that no public money would be needed, with the threat of collapse and the loss of a hundred dozen thousand jobs. A restructuring proposal was also rejected, giving only time to sell off the shipyard assets to Gdynia and Szczecin, leaving the partly privatised Gdansk Shipyard bought by a Ukrainian company. It lacked the will to rebuild the industry in the maritime economies of other Union States. Systematically destroyed for the last thirty years, the shipbuilding industry is now being rebuilt thanks to Poles, the Government of Poland, being one of the largest of its kind in Europe, covering eight large shipyards in Gdańsk, Gdynia, Szczecin and Świnoujście. Shipbuilding is of strategic importance for state security, so it would be important to combat the risks of unfair competition.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Ireland as an island is more dependent on shipping than most EU Member States. The ongoing recklessness of the British Government with regard to Brexit means that it is only prudent to increase shipping capacity in order to avoid Ireland being punished by the likely difficulties in transit of Irish exports through Britain. So shipping and shipbuilding are of increasing importance to Ireland, north and south. The EU strategy to deal with the economic crisis in shipbuilding has been embraced by Harland and Wolff, the largest shipyard in Ireland, which is in the city of Belfast. They have embraced innovation and technology, they are increasingly green and increasingly diversifying into new markets. A lot of the work done in recent years depends on the shipyard and the main ports in the north, namely Belfast Harbour, Warren Point, Larne and, in my home town of Derry, Foyle port, being plugged into the European market, and they all rely on the European supply chains. Brexit is hugely damaging to that plan and risks seriously damaging the industry. Meanwhile the strategy of the British Government seems to depend more on gunboats than on any forward-looking vision for the sector. On this, like on so many other issues, the British Government seem oblivious to the consequences of Brexit for the north of Ireland. This all needs to be factored into the planning of the EU in the time ahead. Solutions do exist to the threats posed by Brexit for each sector, including shipbuilding. We have presented these solutions through our case for designated special status for the north to remain within the EU post-Brexit. In that vein, we have also proposed a system of red and green channels that complement existing infrastructure at ports and could be used to address goods entering and leaving Ireland, north and south. I want to acknowledge the sterling work that is being done by MEP Liadh Ní Riada with regard to protecting the goods that are transiting from Ireland into Britain or via Britain into the EU. So this system would be used for goods transiting through Britain from Ireland to the rest of the EU and would therefore protect the integrity of the single market and allow for east-west trade to continue. We do not want to see the border dividing Ireland being reinforced, nor do we want to see the Irish Sea between Britain and Ireland as an obstacle. Need I remind Members that the Titanic was built in the Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast? Belfast city centre and its Titanic quarter have, as a result of the peace process, community development and European funding, seen a transformation for the better. However, on its first voyage the Titanic hit an iceberg on the North Atlantic and sank. So my appeal to colleagues is don’t let Ireland, north and south, crash on the looming iceberg that is Brexit.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, in its unstoppable drift of regulation, the European Commission has presented a new plan, a so-called comprehensive strategy for the shipbuilding sector. We do not see anything in such plans. First of all, in the plans of the European Commission, I am thinking of interference, nonsensical and superfluous arrangements and opposition to national sovereignty. We stand for the free market economy. Companies themselves are responsible for their success and should not be in the way of European bureaucrats, bureaucrats who have no idea what healthy competition and market forces really are. We are opposed to transferring powers to the European Union. We are opposed to wasting European taxpayers' money by opposing better knowledge in supporting unprofitable companies and bankrupt shipyards. In the past, it has been shown in other sectors that State aid and subsidies are merely postponement of execution. It is often no more than a temporary swab for bleeding. Think, for example, of the aircraft industry and the automotive industry. The Netherlands too has become wise in terms of State aid due to damage and shame. In the 1980s, the Dutch taxpayer paid billions and billions of guilders to support shipyards in our own country, ultimately without success. Large shipyards were closed after a few years and tens of thousands of jobs were lost. So all the taxpayers' money would have been for nothing in the end. In recent years, the shipping industry has flourished again in the Netherlands. Not thanks to the government, but thanks to the power of entrepreneurship and innovation in the sector itself. Ultimately, it is up to the market and not to the government to determine where and when which goods are produced. It is a question of supply and demand, price and quality. Basically, stop using the so-called utilities, Stop the European subsidy infusion, curb the drift and leave the shipping industry alone!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Mr President, honourable Members, I thank my colleague Jakovcic for raising this extremely important issue. Many countries in the European Union have a tradition of shipbuilding, and at the moment this industry is under threat. And separately is the question, which is being raised continuously, of the so-called reindustrialisation of Europe and of the European Union. We need such efforts, we need to preserve these traditions. We need to keep those jobs. We have competition — not very fair — from countries outside the European Union who are quite logically and quite normally trying to enter these markets. And it is up to us alone — on our joint efforts as the European Parliament and the European Union, whether we succeed in protecting our own production and our own jobs. (The speaker agrees to answer the question 'blue card' (Rule 162 (8))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card question. — Thank you very much, dear Mr. Dzhambacki, for accepting my blue card question! My country, Latvia, joined the European Union in 2004. Bulgaria joined Romania later in 2007. There are things in my country that we have lost, objectively judged, in the shipping industry and in the shipbuilding sector, but a lot we have got - for our industry, needs, people and all our business. How is your country? What have you lost in the meantime and what has got?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Answer to a question asked by raising a blue card. — Thanks for the question, colleague Mamikins, you are right: the entry into the European Union of both Latvia and Bulgaria is a matter of negotiation and negotiation. Yes, initially there were job losses, but it also provides an opportunity for future development. Currently in Bulgaria there are two operating state-owned shipyards and several active private ones. And they have treaties with other European Union countries. So, within the Union, we should cooperate. Moreover, we should also cooperate in the field of military production, where we can achieve good results.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank everyone for their remarks. I think that the shipyard and maritime industry is so important that we probably need to take action – even more action than we’ve being doing so far – for the next 18 months. As I mentioned our LeaderSHIP 2020 programme – which is the right framework and which provided the necessary orientation to our industries to embrace the new challenges, new opportunities to discuss innovation, the circular economy, and digitalisation – I am confident that while of course it cannot be fast, because we are jointly discussing it and making joint efforts with all stakeholders involved, it will continue to deliver useful results in the future. Member States, of course, have a key role in ensuring that the industry meets new challenges and takes advantage of the opportunities. Of course, we have to continue to work both with the Member States, with the Parliament, and with the stakeholders in the industry, but I can commit to you that I will look in those fields where our activities should be stronger and where our action can really make a difference, including access to finance, including access to markets. We are doing a lot on skills. We are doing a lot on access to markets, but I think that we will maybe get some new perspective while creating them, discussing the new budget generally on the industry – but in this framework also for the shipyard industry – so this is not the end of our discussion.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
